5    *Text Alternatives*: 5    *Text Alternatives*:
6    Understanding Guideline 1.1 6    Understanding Guideline 1.1
7  7 
8    *Guideline 1.1: *Provide text alternatives for any non-text content 8    *Guideline 1.1: *Provide text alternatives for any non-text content
9    so that it can be changed into other forms people need, such as 9    so that it can be changed into other forms people need, such as
10    large print, braille, speech, symbols or simpler language. 10    large print, braille, speech, symbols or simpler language.
11  11 
12  12 
13      Intent of Guideline 1.1 13      Intent of Guideline 1.1
14  14 
15The purpose of this guideline is to ensure that all non-text content is 15The purpose of this guideline is to ensure that all non-text content is
16also available in text 16also available in text
17<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#textdef>. "Text" refers 17<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#textdef>. "Text" refers
18to electronic text, not an image of text. Electronic text has the unique 18to electronic text, not an image of text. Electronic text has the unique
19advantage that it is presentation neutral. That is, it can be rendered 19advantage that it is presentation neutral. That is, it can be rendered
20visually, auditorily, tactilely, or by any combination. As a result, 20visually, auditorily, tactilely, or by any combination. As a result,
21information rendered in electronic text can be presented in whatever 21information rendered in electronic text can be presented in whatever
22form best meets the needs of the user. It can also be easily enlarged, 22form best meets the needs of the user. It can also be easily enlarged,
23spoken aloud so that it is easier for people with reading disabilities 23spoken aloud so that it is easier for people with reading disabilities
24to understand, or rendered in whatever tactile form best meets the needs 24to understand, or rendered in whatever tactile form best meets the needs
25of a user. 25of a user.
26  26 
27/Note: /While changing the content into symbols includes changing it 27/Note: /While changing the content into symbols includes changing it
28into graphic symbols for people with developmental disorders and speech 28into graphic symbols for people with developmental disorders and speech
29comprehension difficulties, it is not limited to this use of symbols. 29comprehension difficulties, it is not limited to this use of symbols.

32      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 1.1 (not success criteria specific) 32      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 1.1 (not success criteria specific)
33  33 
34Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this 34Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this
35guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success 35guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success
36Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for 36Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for
37addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success 37addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success
38criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or 38criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or
39sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types 39sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types
40of Web content more accessible to more people. 40of Web content more accessible to more people.

111  111 
112  112 
113      Intent of this Success Criterion 113      Intent of this Success Criterion
114  114 
115The intent of this Success Criterion is to make information conveyed by 115The intent of this Success Criterion is to make information conveyed by
116non-text content accessible through the use of a text alternative. Text 116non-text content accessible through the use of a text alternative. Text
117alternatives are a primary way for making information accessible because 117alternatives are a primary way for making information accessible because
118they can be rendered through any sensory modality (for example, visual, 118they can be rendered through any sensory modality (for example, visual,
119auditory or tactile) to match the needs of the user. Providing text 119auditory or tactile) to match the needs of the user. Providing text
120alternatives allows the information to be rendered in a variety of ways 120alternatives allows the information to be rendered in a variety of ways
121by a variety of user agents. For example, a person who cannot see a 121by a variety of user agents. For example, a person who cannot see a
122picture can have the text alternative read aloud using synthesized 122picture can have the text alternative read aloud using synthesized
123speech. A person who cannot hear an audio file can have the text 123speech. A person who cannot hear an audio file can have the text
124alternative displayed so that he or she can read it. In the future, text 124alternative displayed so that he or she can read it. In the future, text
125alternatives will also allow information to be more easily translated 125alternatives will also allow information to be more easily translated
126into sign language or into a simpler form of the same language. 126into sign language or into a simpler form of the same language.
127  127 
128  128 
129        Note on CAPTCHA 129        Note on CAPTCHA
130  130 
131CAPTCHAs are a controversial topic in the accessibility community. As is 131CAPTCHAs are a controversial topic in the accessibility community. As is
132described in the paper Inaccessibility of CAPTCHA 132described in the paper Inaccessibility of CAPTCHA
133<http://www.w3.org/TR/turingtest/>, CAPTCHAs intrinsically push the 133<http://www.w3.org/TR/turingtest/>, CAPTCHAs intrinsically push the
134edges of human abilities in an attempt to defeat automated processes. 134edges of human abilities in an attempt to defeat automated processes.
135Every type of CAPTCHA will be unsolvable by users with certain 135Every type of CAPTCHA will be unsolvable by users with certain
136disabilities. However, they are widely used, and the Web Content 136disabilities. However, they are widely used, and the Web Content
137Accessibility Guidelines Working Group believes that if CAPTCHAs were 137Accessibility Guidelines Working Group believes that if CAPTCHAs were
138forbidden outright, Web sites would choose not to conform to WCAG rather 138forbidden outright, Web sites would choose not to conform to WCAG rather
139than abandon CAPTCHA. This would create barriers for a great many more 139than abandon CAPTCHA. This would create barriers for a great many more
140users with disabilities. For this reason the Working Group has chosen to 140users with disabilities. For this reason the Working Group has chosen to
141structure the requirement about CAPTCHA in a way that meets the needs of 141structure the requirement about CAPTCHA in a way that meets the needs of
142most people with disabilities, yet is also considered adoptable by 142most people with disabilities, yet is also considered adoptable by
143sites. Requiring two different forms of CAPTCHA on a given site ensures 143sites. Requiring two different forms of CAPTCHA on a given site ensures
144that most people with disabilities will find a form they can use. 144that most people with disabilities will find a form they can use.
145  145 
146Because some users with disabilities will still not be able to access 146Because some users with disabilities will still not be able to access
147sites that meet the minimum requirements, the Working Group provides 147sites that meet the minimum requirements, the Working Group provides
148recommendations for additional steps. Organizations motivated to conform 148recommendations for additional steps. Organizations motivated to conform
149to WCAG should be aware of the importance of this topic and should go as 149to WCAG should be aware of the importance of this topic and should go as
150far beyond the minimum requirements of the guidelines as possible. 150far beyond the minimum requirements of the guidelines as possible.
151Additional recommended steps include: 151Additional recommended steps include:

168  168 
169Non-text content can take a number of forms, and this Success Criterion 169Non-text content can take a number of forms, and this Success Criterion
170specifies how each is to be handled. 170specifies how each is to be handled.
171  171 
172*For non-text content that is not covered by one of the other situations 172*For non-text content that is not covered by one of the other situations
173listed below,* such as charts, diagrams, audio recordings, pictures, and 173listed below,* such as charts, diagrams, audio recordings, pictures, and
174animations, text alternatives can make the same information available in 174animations, text alternatives can make the same information available in
175a form that can be rendered through any modality (for example, visual, 175a form that can be rendered through any modality (for example, visual,
176auditory or tactile). Short and long text alternatives can be used as 176auditory or tactile). Short and long text alternatives can be used as
177needed to convey the information in the non-text content. Note that 177needed to convey the information in the non-text content. Note that
178*prerecorded audio-only* and *prerecorded video-only* files are covered 178*prerecorded audio-only* and *prerecorded video-only* files are covered
179here. *Live-audio-only* and *Live-video-only* files are covered below 179here. *Live-audio-only* and *Live-video-only* files are covered below
180(see 3rd paragraph following this one). 180(see 3rd paragraph following this one).
181  181 
182*For non-text content that is a control or accepts user input*, such as 182*For non-text content that is a control or accepts user input*, such as
183images used as submit buttons, image maps or complex animations, a name 183images used as submit buttons, image maps or complex animations, a name
184is provided to describe the purpose of the non-text content so that the 184is provided to describe the purpose of the non-text content so that the
185person at least knows what the non-text content is and why it is there. 185person at least knows what the non-text content is and why it is there.
186  186 
187*Non-text content that is time-based media* is made accessible through 187*Non-text content that is time-based media* is made accessible through
188/1.2 <#media-equiv>/. However, it is important that users know what it 188/1.2 <#media-equiv>/. However, it is important that users know what it
189is when they encounter it on a page so they can decide what action if 189is when they encounter it on a page so they can decide what action if
190any they want to take with it. A text alternative that describes the 190any they want to take with it. A text alternative that describes the
191time-based media and/or gives its title is therefore provided. 191time-based media and/or gives its title is therefore provided.
192  192 
193*For Live Audio-only and live video-only content*, it can be much more 193*For Live Audio-only and live video-only content*, it can be much more
194difficult to provide text alternatives that provide equivalent 194difficult to provide text alternatives that provide equivalent
195information as live audio-only and live video-only content. For these 195information as live audio-only and live video-only content. For these
196types of non-text content, text alternatives provide a descriptive label. 196types of non-text content, text alternatives provide a descriptive label.
197  197 
198*Sometimes a test or exercise must be partially or completely presented 198*Sometimes a test or exercise must be partially or completely presented
199in non-text format.* Audio or visual information is provided that cannot 199in non-text format.* Audio or visual information is provided that cannot
200be changed to text because the test or exercise must be conducted using 200be changed to text because the test or exercise must be conducted using
201that sense. For example, a hearing test would be invalid if a text 201that sense. For example, a hearing test would be invalid if a text
202alternative were provided. A visual skill development exercise would 202alternative were provided. A visual skill development exercise would
203similarly make no sense in text form. And a spelling test with text 203similarly make no sense in text form. And a spelling test with text
204alternatives would not be very effective. For these cases, text 204alternatives would not be very effective. For these cases, text
205alternatives should be provided to describe the purpose of the non-text 205alternatives should be provided to describe the purpose of the non-text
206content; of course, the text alternatives would not provide the same 206content; of course, the text alternatives would not provide the same
207information needed to pass the test. 207information needed to pass the test.
208  208 
209*Sometimes content is primarily intended to create a specific sensory 209*Sometimes content is primarily intended to create a specific sensory
210experience* that words cannot fully capture. Examples include a symphony 210experience* that words cannot fully capture. Examples include a symphony
211performance, works of visual art etc. For such content, text 211performance, works of visual art etc. For such content, text
212alternatives at least identify the non-text content with a descriptive 212alternatives at least identify the non-text content with a descriptive
213label and where possible, additional descriptive text. If the reason for 213label and where possible, additional descriptive text. If the reason for
214including the content in the page is known and can be described it is 214including the content in the page is known and can be described it is
215helpful to include that information. 215helpful to include that information.
216  216 
217*Sometimes there are non-text exercises that are used to prove you are 217*Sometimes there are non-text exercises that are used to prove you are
218human.* To avoid spam robots and other software from gaining access to a 218human.* To avoid spam robots and other software from gaining access to a
219site a device called a CAPTCHA is used. These usually involve visual or 219site a device called a CAPTCHA is used. These usually involve visual or
220auditory tasks that are beyond the current capabilities of Web robots. 220auditory tasks that are beyond the current capabilities of Web robots.
221Providing a text alternative to them would however make them operable by 221Providing a text alternative to them would however make them operable by
222Robots, thus defeating their purpose. In this case a text alternative 222Robots, thus defeating their purpose. In this case a text alternative
223would describe the purpose of the CAPTCHA, and alternate forms using 223would describe the purpose of the CAPTCHA, and alternate forms using
224different modalities would be provided to address the needs of people 224different modalities would be provided to address the needs of people
225with different disabilities. 225with different disabilities.
226  226 
227*Sometimes there is non-text content that really is not meant to be seen 227*Sometimes there is non-text content that really is not meant to be seen
228or understood by the user.* Transparent images used to move text over on 228or understood by the user.* Transparent images used to move text over on
229a page; an invisible image that is used to track usage statistics; and a 229a page; an invisible image that is used to track usage statistics; and a
230swirl in the corner that conveys no information but just fills up a 230swirl in the corner that conveys no information but just fills up a
231blank space to create an aesthetic effect are all examples of this. 231blank space to create an aesthetic effect are all examples of this.
232Putting alternative text on such items just distracts people using 232Putting alternative text on such items just distracts people using
233screen readers from the content on the page. Not marking the content in 233screen readers from the content on the page. Not marking the content in
234any way, though, leaves users guessing what the non-text content is and 234any way, though, leaves users guessing what the non-text content is and
235what information they may have missed (even though they have not missed 235what information they may have missed (even though they have not missed
236anything in reality). This type of non-text content, therefore, is 236anything in reality). This type of non-text content, therefore, is
237marked or implemented in a way that assistive technologies (AT) will 237marked or implemented in a way that assistive technologies (AT) will
238ignore it and not present anything to the user. 238ignore it and not present anything to the user.

245    This Success Criterion helps people who have difficulty perceiving 245    This Success Criterion helps people who have difficulty perceiving
246    visual content. Assistive technology can read text aloud, present it 246    visual content. Assistive technology can read text aloud, present it
247    visually, or convert it to braille. 247    visually, or convert it to braille.

251    Text alternatives may help some people who have difficulty 251    Text alternatives may help some people who have difficulty
252    understanding the meaning of photographs, drawings, and other images 252    understanding the meaning of photographs, drawings, and other images
253    (e.g., line drawings, graphic designs, paintings, three-dimensional 253    (e.g., line drawings, graphic designs, paintings, three-dimensional
254    representations), graphs, charts, animations, etc. 254    representations), graphs, charts, animations, etc.

257  257 
258    People who are deaf, are hard of hearing, or who are having trouble 258    People who are deaf, are hard of hearing, or who are having trouble
259    understanding audio information for any reason can read the text 259    understanding audio information for any reason can read the text
260    presentation. Research is ongoing regarding automatic translation of 260    presentation. Research is ongoing regarding automatic translation of
261    text into sign language. 261    text into sign language.

275 1. 275 1.
276  276 
277    *A data chart* 277    *A data chart*
278  278 
279    A bar chart compares how many widgets were sold in June, July, and 279    A bar chart compares how many widgets were sold in June, July, and
280    August. The short label says, "Figure one - Sales in June, July and 280    August. The short label says, "Figure one - Sales in June, July and
281    August." The longer description identifies the type of chart, 281    August." The longer description identifies the type of chart,
282    provides a high-level summary of the data, trends and implications 282    provides a high-level summary of the data, trends and implications
283    comparable to those available from the chart. Where possible and 283    comparable to those available from the chart. Where possible and
284    practical, the actual data is provided in a table. 284    practical, the actual data is provided in a table.
285  285 
286 2. 286 2.
287  287 
288    *An audio recording of a speech* 288    *An audio recording of a speech*
289  289 
290    The link to an audio clip says, "Chairman's speech to the assembly." 290    The link to an audio clip says, "Chairman's speech to the assembly."
291    A link to a text transcript is provided immediately after the link 291    A link to a text transcript is provided immediately after the link
292    to the audio clip. 292    to the audio clip.
293  293 
294 3. 294 3.
295  295 
296    *An animation that illustrates how a car engine works* 296    *An animation that illustrates how a car engine works*
297  297 
298    An animation shows how a car engine works. There is no audio and the 298    An animation shows how a car engine works. There is no audio and the
299    animation is part of a tutorial that describes how an engine works. 299    animation is part of a tutorial that describes how an engine works.
300    Since the text of the tutorial already provides a full explanation, 300    Since the text of the tutorial already provides a full explanation,
301    the image is an alternative for text and the text alternative 301    the image is an alternative for text and the text alternative
302    includes only a brief description of the animation and refers to the 302    includes only a brief description of the animation and refers to the
303    tutorial text for more information. 303    tutorial text for more information.

306  306 
307    *A traffic Web camera* 307    *A traffic Web camera*
308  308 
309    A Web site allows users to select from a variety of Web cameras 309    A Web site allows users to select from a variety of Web cameras
310    positioned throughout a major city. After a camera is selected, the 310    positioned throughout a major city. After a camera is selected, the
311    image updates every two minutes. A short text alternative identifies 311    image updates every two minutes. A short text alternative identifies
312    the Web camera as "traffic Web camera." The site also provides a 312    the Web camera as "traffic Web camera." The site also provides a
313    table of travel times for each of the routes covered by the Web 313    table of travel times for each of the routes covered by the Web
314    cameras. The table is also updated every two minutes. 314    cameras. The table is also updated every two minutes.

321    story about an international summit meeting. The text alternative 321    story about an international summit meeting. The text alternative
322    says, "President X of Country X shakes hands with Prime Minister Y 322    says, "President X of Country X shakes hands with Prime Minister Y
323    of country Y." 323    of country Y."

326  326 
327    *A photograph of a historic event in content discussing diplomatic 327    *A photograph of a historic event in content discussing diplomatic
328    relationships* 328    relationships*
329  329 
330    The same image is used in a different context intended to explain 330    The same image is used in a different context intended to explain
331    nuances in diplomatic encounters. The image of the president shaking 331    nuances in diplomatic encounters. The image of the president shaking
332    hands with the prime minister appears on a Web site discussing 332    hands with the prime minister appears on a Web site discussing
333    intricate diplomatic relationships. The first text alternative 333    intricate diplomatic relationships. The first text alternative
334    reads, "President X of country X shakes hands with Prime Minister Y 334    reads, "President X of country X shakes hands with Prime Minister Y
335    of country Y on January 2, 2009." An additional text alternative 335    of country Y on January 2, 2009." An additional text alternative
336    describes the room where the leaders are standing as well as the 336    describes the room where the leaders are standing as well as the
337    expressions on the leaders' faces, and identifies the other people 337    expressions on the leaders' faces, and identifies the other people
338    in the room. The additional description might be included on the 338    in the room. The additional description might be included on the
339    same page as the photograph or in a separate file associated with 339    same page as the photograph or in a separate file associated with
340    the image through a link or other standard programmatic mechanism. 340    the image through a link or other standard programmatic mechanism.
341  341 
342 7. 342 7.
343  343 
344    *An audio recording of a press conference * 344    *An audio recording of a press conference *
345  345 
346    A Web page includes a link to an audio recording of a press 346    A Web page includes a link to an audio recording of a press
347    conference. The link text identifies the audio recording. The page 347    conference. The link text identifies the audio recording. The page
348    also links to a text transcript of the press conference. The 348    also links to a text transcript of the press conference. The
349    transcript includes a verbatim record of everything the speakers 349    transcript includes a verbatim record of everything the speakers
350    say. It identifies who is speaking as well as noting other 350    say. It identifies who is speaking as well as noting other
351    significant sounds that are part of the recording, such as applause, 351    significant sounds that are part of the recording, such as applause,
352    laughter, questions from the audience, and so on. 352    laughter, questions from the audience, and so on.
353  353

355  355 
356    *An e-learning application * 356    *An e-learning application *
357  357 
358    An e-learning application uses sound effects to indicate whether or 358    An e-learning application uses sound effects to indicate whether or
359    not the answers are correct. The chime sound indicates that the 359    not the answers are correct. The chime sound indicates that the
360    answer is correct and the beep sound indicates that the answer is 360    answer is correct and the beep sound indicates that the answer is
361    incorrect. A text description is also included so that people who 361    incorrect. A text description is also included so that people who
362    can't hear or understand the sound understand whether the answer is 362    can't hear or understand the sound understand whether the answer is
363    correct or incorrect. 363    correct or incorrect.

370    page of the "Smallville Times". The text alternative says 370    page of the "Smallville Times". The text alternative says
371    "Smallville Times". 371    "Smallville Times".

378    world that is used on a travel site as a link to the International 378    world that is used on a travel site as a link to the International
379    Travel section has the text alternative "International Travel". The 379    Travel section has the text alternative "International Travel". The

438of techniques that the WCAG Working Group deems sufficient for meeting 438of techniques that the WCAG Working Group deems sufficient for meeting
439this Success Criterion. The techniques listed only satisfy the Success 439this Success Criterion. The techniques listed only satisfy the Success
440Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements 440Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements
441<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have 441<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have
442been met. 442been met.

450situation. 450situation.

978  978 
979      Key Terms 979      Key Terms
980  980 
981CAPTCHA 981CAPTCHA
982  982 
983    initialism for "Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell 983    initialism for "Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell
984    Computers and Humans Apart" 984    Computers and Humans Apart"
985  985 
986    /Note 1: /CAPTCHA tests often involve asking the user to type in 986    /Note 1: /CAPTCHA tests often involve asking the user to type in
987    text that is displayed in an obscured image or audio file. 987    text that is displayed in an obscured image or audio file.
988  988 
989    /Note 2: /A Turing test is any system of tests designed to 989    /Note 2: /A Turing test is any system of tests designed to
990    differentiate a human from a computer. It is named after famed 990    differentiate a human from a computer. It is named after famed
991    computer scientist Alan Turing. The term was coined by researchers 991    computer scientist Alan Turing. The term was coined by researchers
992    at Carnegie Mellon University. [CAPTCHA] <#CAPTCHA> 992    at Carnegie Mellon University. [CAPTCHA] <#CAPTCHA>
993  993 
994assistive technology (as used in this document) 994assistive technology (as used in this document)
995  995 
996    hardware and/or software that acts as a user agent 996    hardware and/or software that acts as a user agent
997    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#useragentdef>, or 997    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#useragentdef>, or
998    along with a mainstream user agent, to provide functionality to meet 998    along with a mainstream user agent, to provide functionality to meet
999    the requirements of users with disabilities that go beyond those 999    the requirements of users with disabilities that go beyond those
1000    offered by mainstream user agents 1000    offered by mainstream user agents
1001  1001 
1002    /Note 1: / functionality provided by assistive technology includes 1002    /Note 1: / functionality provided by assistive technology includes
1003    alternative presentations (e.g., as synthesized speech or magnified 1003    alternative presentations (e.g., as synthesized speech or magnified
1004    content), alternative input methods (e.g., voice), additional 1004    content), alternative input methods (e.g., voice), additional
1005    navigation or orientation mechanisms, and content transformations 1005    navigation or orientation mechanisms, and content transformations
1006    (e.g., to make tables more accessible). 1006    (e.g., to make tables more accessible).
1007  1007

1009    with mainstream user agents by using and monitoring APIs. 1009    with mainstream user agents by using and monitoring APIs.
1010  1010 
1011    /Note 3: /The distinction between mainstream user agents and 1011    /Note 3: /The distinction between mainstream user agents and
1012    assistive technologies is not absolute. Many mainstream user agents 1012    assistive technologies is not absolute. Many mainstream user agents
1013    provide some features to assist individuals with disabilities. The 1013    provide some features to assist individuals with disabilities. The
1014    basic difference is that mainstream user agents target broad and 1014    basic difference is that mainstream user agents target broad and
1015    diverse audiences that usually include people with and without 1015    diverse audiences that usually include people with and without
1016    disabilities. Assistive technologies target narrowly defined 1016    disabilities. Assistive technologies target narrowly defined
1017    populations of users with specific disabilities. The assistance 1017    populations of users with specific disabilities. The assistance
1018    provided by an assistive technology is more specific and appropriate 1018    provided by an assistive technology is more specific and appropriate
1019    to the needs of its target users. The mainstream user agent may 1019    to the needs of its target users. The mainstream user agent may
1020    provide important functionality to assistive technologies like 1020    provide important functionality to assistive technologies like

1022    identifiable bundles. 1022    identifiable bundles.

1263The intent of this Success Criterion is to make information conveyed by 1263The intent of this Success Criterion is to make information conveyed by
1264prerecorded audio-only and prerecorded video-only content available to 1264prerecorded audio-only and prerecorded video-only content available to
1265all users. Alternatives for time-based media that are text based make 1265all users. Alternatives for time-based media that are text based make
1266information accessible because text can be rendered through any sensory 1266information accessible because text can be rendered through any sensory
1267modality (for example, visual, auditory or tactile) to match the needs 1267modality (for example, visual, auditory or tactile) to match the needs
1268of the user. In the future, text could also be translated into symbols, 1268of the user. In the future, text could also be translated into symbols,
1269sign language or simpler forms of the language (future). 1269sign language or simpler forms of the language (future).

1272interaction is a silent movie. The purpose of the transcript is to 1272interaction is a silent movie. The purpose of the transcript is to
1273provide an equivalent to what is presented visually. For prerecorded 1273provide an equivalent to what is presented visually. For prerecorded
1274video content, authors have the option to provide an audio track. The 1274video content, authors have the option to provide an audio track. The
1275purpose of the audio alternative is to be an equivalent to the video. 1275purpose of the audio alternative is to be an equivalent to the video.
1276This makes it possible for users with and without vision impairment to 1276This makes it possible for users with and without vision impairment to
1277review content simultaneously. The approach can also make it easier for 1277review content simultaneously. The approach can also make it easier for
1278those with cognitive, language and learning disabilities to understand 1278those with cognitive, language and learning disabilities to understand
1279the content because it would provide parallel presentation. 1279the content because it would provide parallel presentation.

1326  1326 
1327    The link to an audio clip says, "Chairman's speech to the assembly." 1327    The link to an audio clip says, "Chairman's speech to the assembly."
1328    A link to a text transcript is provided immediately after the link 1328    A link to a text transcript is provided immediately after the link
1329    to the audio clip. 1329    to the audio clip.
1330  1330 
1331  * 1331  *
1332  1332 
1333    *An audio recording of a press conference* 1333    *An audio recording of a press conference*
1334  1334 
1335    A Web page includes a link to an audio recording of a press 1335    A Web page includes a link to an audio recording of a press
1336    conference that identifies the audio recording. The page also links 1336    conference that identifies the audio recording. The page also links
1337    to a text transcript of the press conference. The transcript 1337    to a text transcript of the press conference. The transcript
1338    includes a verbatim record of everything the speakers say. It 1338    includes a verbatim record of everything the speakers say. It
1339    identifies who is speaking as well as noting other significant 1339    identifies who is speaking as well as noting other significant
1340    sounds that are part of the recording, such as applause, laughter, 1340    sounds that are part of the recording, such as applause, laughter,
1341    questions from the audience, and so on. 1341    questions from the audience, and so on.
1342  1342 
1343  * 1343  *
1344  1344 
1345    *An animation that illustrates how a car engine works* 1345    *An animation that illustrates how a car engine works*
1346  1346 
1347    An animation shows how a car engine works. There is no audio and the 1347    An animation shows how a car engine works. There is no audio and the
1348    animation is part of a tutorial that describes how an engine works. 1348    animation is part of a tutorial that describes how an engine works.
1349    Since the text of the tutorial already provides a full explanation, 1349    Since the text of the tutorial already provides a full explanation,
1350    the media is an alternative for text and the text alternative 1350    the media is an alternative for text and the text alternative
1351    includes only a brief description of the animation and refers to the 1351    includes only a brief description of the animation and refers to the
1352    tutorial text for more information. 1352    tutorial text for more information.

1359    of the action in the video. 1359    of the action in the video.

1535    and is clearly labeled as such. (Level A) 1535    and is clearly labeled as such. (Level A)
1536  1536 
1537  1537 
1538      Intent of this Success Criterion 1538      Intent of this Success Criterion
1539  1539 
1540The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable people who are deaf or 1540The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable people who are deaf or
1541hard of hearing to watch synchronized media presentations. Captions 1541hard of hearing to watch synchronized media presentations. Captions
1542provide the part of the content available via the audio track. Captions 1542provide the part of the content available via the audio track. Captions
1543not only include dialogue, but identify who is speaking and include 1543not only include dialogue, but identify who is speaking and include
1544non-speech information conveyed through sound, including meaningful 1544non-speech information conveyed through sound, including meaningful
1545sound effects. 1545sound effects.
1546  1546 
1547It is acknowledged that at the present time there may be difficulty in 1547It is acknowledged that at the present time there may be difficulty in
1548creating captions for time-sensitive material and this may result in the 1548creating captions for time-sensitive material and this may result in the
1549author being faced with the choice of delaying the information until 1549author being faced with the choice of delaying the information until
1550captions are available, or publishing time-sensitive content that is 1550captions are available, or publishing time-sensitive content that is
1551inaccessible to the deaf, at least for the interval until captions are 1551inaccessible to the deaf, at least for the interval until captions are
1552available. Over time, the tools for captioning as well as building the 1552available. Over time, the tools for captioning as well as building the
1553captioning into the delivery process can shorten or eliminate such delays. 1553captioning into the delivery process can shorten or eliminate such delays.
1554  1554 
1555Captions are not needed when the synchronized media is, itself, an 1555Captions are not needed when the synchronized media is, itself, an
1556alternate presentation of information that is also presented via text on 1556alternate presentation of information that is also presented via text on
1557the Web page. For example, if information on a page is accompanied by a 1557the Web page. For example, if information on a page is accompanied by a
1558synchronized media presentation that presents no more information than 1558synchronized media presentation that presents no more information than
1559is already presented in text, but is easier for people with cognitive, 1559is already presented in text, but is easier for people with cognitive,
1560language, or learning disabilities to understand, then it would not need 1560language, or learning disabilities to understand, then it would not need
1561to be captioned since the information is already presented on the page 1561to be captioned since the information is already presented on the page
1562in text or in text alternatives (e.g., for images). 1562in text or in text alternatives (e.g., for images).
1563  1563

1565<#media-equiv-real-time-captions>/. 1565<#media-equiv-real-time-captions>/.

1596    paragraph. Each clip is associated with its corresponding paragraph. 1596    paragraph. Each clip is associated with its corresponding paragraph.

1603    showing the part in its correct orientation. No captions are 1603    showing the part in its correct orientation. No captions are
1604    provided for the synchronized media clip. 1604    provided for the synchronized media clip.

1886  1886 
1887  1887 
1888      Intent of this Success Criterion 1888      Intent of this Success Criterion
1889  1889 
1890The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide people who are blind 1890The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide people who are blind
1891or visually impaired access to the visual information in a synchronized 1891or visually impaired access to the visual information in a synchronized
1892media presentation. This Success Criterion describes two approaches, 1892media presentation. This Success Criterion describes two approaches,
1893either of which can be used. 1893either of which can be used.
1894  1894 
1895One approach is to provide audio description of the video content. The 1895One approach is to provide audio description of the video content. The
1896audio description augments the audio portion of the presentation with 1896audio description augments the audio portion of the presentation with
1897the information needed when the video portion is not available. During 1897the information needed when the video portion is not available. During
1898existing pauses in dialogue, audio description provides information 1898existing pauses in dialogue, audio description provides information
1899about actions, characters, scene changes, and on-screen text that are 1899about actions, characters, scene changes, and on-screen text that are
1900important and are not described or spoken in the main sound track. 1900important and are not described or spoken in the main sound track.
1901  1901 
1902The second approach involves providing all of the information in the 1902The second approach involves providing all of the information in the
1903synchronized media (both visual and auditory) in text form. An 1903synchronized media (both visual and auditory) in text form. An
1904alternative for time-based media provides a running description of all 1904alternative for time-based media provides a running description of all
1905that is going on in the synchronized media content. The alternative for 1905that is going on in the synchronized media content. The alternative for
1906time-based media reads something like a screenplay or book. Unlike audio 1906time-based media reads something like a screenplay or book. Unlike audio
1907description, the description of the video portion is not constrained to 1907description, the description of the video portion is not constrained to
1908just the pauses in the existing dialogue. Full descriptions are provided 1908just the pauses in the existing dialogue. Full descriptions are provided
1909of all visual information, including visual context, actions and 1909of all visual information, including visual context, actions and
1910expressions of actors, and any other visual material. In addition, 1910expressions of actors, and any other visual material. In addition,
1911non-speech sounds (laughter, off-screen voices, etc.) are described, and 1911non-speech sounds (laughter, off-screen voices, etc.) are described, and
1912transcripts of all dialogue are included. The sequence of description 1912transcripts of all dialogue are included. The sequence of description
1913and dialogue transcripts are the same as the sequence in the 1913and dialogue transcripts are the same as the sequence in the
1914synchronized media itself. As a result, the alternative for time-based 1914synchronized media itself. As a result, the alternative for time-based
1915media can provide a much more complete representation of the 1915media can provide a much more complete representation of the
1916synchronized media content than audio description alone. 1916synchronized media content than audio description alone.
1917  1917 
1918If there is any interaction as part of the synchronized media 1918If there is any interaction as part of the synchronized media
1919presentation (e.g., "press now to answer the question") then the 1919presentation (e.g., "press now to answer the question") then the
1920alternative for time-based media would provide hyperlinks or whatever is 1920alternative for time-based media would provide hyperlinks or whatever is
1921needed to provide the same functionality. 1921needed to provide the same functionality.
1922  1922 
1923/Note 1: / For 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.7, if all of the information in the 1923/Note 1: / For 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.7, if all of the information in the
1924video track is already provided in the audio track, no audio description 1924video track is already provided in the audio track, no audio description
1925is necessary. 1925is necessary.
1926  1926 
1927/Note 2: / 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.8 overlap somewhat with each other. 1927/Note 2: / 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.8 overlap somewhat with each other.
1928This is to give the author some choice at the minimum conformance level, 1928This is to give the author some choice at the minimum conformance level,
1929and to provide additional requirements at higher levels. At Level A in 1929and to provide additional requirements at higher levels. At Level A in
1930Success Criterion 1.2.3, authors do have the choice of providing either 1930Success Criterion 1.2.3, authors do have the choice of providing either
1931an audio description or a full text alternative. If they wish to conform 1931an audio description or a full text alternative. If they wish to conform
1932at Level AA, under Success Criterion 1.2.5 authors must provide an audio 1932at Level AA, under Success Criterion 1.2.5 authors must provide an audio
1933description - a requirement already met if they chose that alternative 1933description - a requirement already met if they chose that alternative
1934for 1.2.3, otherwise an additional requirement. At Level AAA under 1934for 1.2.3, otherwise an additional requirement. At Level AAA under
1935Success Criterion 1.2.8 they must provide an extended text description. 1935Success Criterion 1.2.8 they must provide an extended text description.
1936This is an additional requirement if both 1.2.3 and 1.2.5 were met by 1936This is an additional requirement if both 1.2.3 and 1.2.5 were met by
1937providing an audio description only. If 1.2.3 was met, however, by 1937providing an audio description only. If 1.2.3 was met, however, by
1938providing a text description, and the 1.2.5 requirement for an audio 1938providing a text description, and the 1.2.5 requirement for an audio
1939description was met, then 1.2.8 does not add new requirements. 1939description was met, then 1.2.8 does not add new requirements.
1940  1940

1949  1949 
1950  * 1950  *
1951  1951 
1952    This Success Criterion may help some people who have difficulty 1952    This Success Criterion may help some people who have difficulty
1953    watching video or other synchronized media content, including people 1953    watching video or other synchronized media content, including people
1954    who have difficulty perceiving or understanding moving images. 1954    who have difficulty perceiving or understanding moving images.

1961    *A movie with audio description.* 1961    *A movie with audio description.*
1962  1962 
1963    *Describer: *A title, "Teaching Evolution Case Studies. Bonnie 1963    *Describer: *A title, "Teaching Evolution Case Studies. Bonnie
1964    Chen." A teacher shows photographs of birds with long, thin beaks. 1964    Chen." A teacher shows photographs of birds with long, thin beaks.
1965  1965 
1966    *Bonnie Chen: *"These photos were all taken at the Everglades." 1966    *Bonnie Chen: *"These photos were all taken at the Everglades."
1967  1967 
1968    *Describer: *The teacher hands each student two flat, thin wooden 1968    *Describer: *The teacher hands each student two flat, thin wooden
1969    sticks. 1969    sticks.
1970  1970 
1971    *Bonnie Chen: *"Today you will pretend to be a species of wading 1971    *Bonnie Chen: *"Today you will pretend to be a species of wading

1987    puts it on the companies intranet. The video involves explaining use 1987    puts it on the companies intranet. The video involves explaining use

1989    the same time. Since there is no place to insert audio description 1989    the same time. Since there is no place to insert audio description
1990    of the visual demonstrations during gaps in dialogue, the company 1990    of the visual demonstrations during gaps in dialogue, the company
1991    provides an alternative for time-based media that all employees, 1991    provides an alternative for time-based media that all employees,

2254    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#synchronizedmediadef>. 2254    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#synchronizedmediadef>.

2256  2256 
2257  2257 
2258      Intent of this Success Criterion 2258      Intent of this Success Criterion
2259  2259 
2260The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable people who are deaf or 2260The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable people who are deaf or
2261hard of hearing to watch */real-time/* presentations. Captions provide 2261hard of hearing to watch */real-time/* presentations. Captions provide
2262the part of the content available via the audio track. Captions not only 2262the part of the content available via the audio track. Captions not only
2263include dialogue, but also identify who is speaking and notate sound 2263include dialogue, but also identify who is speaking and notate sound
2264effects and other significant audio. 2264effects and other significant audio.

2269  * 2269  *
2270  2270 
2271    People who are deaf or have a hearing loss can access the auditory 2271    People who are deaf or have a hearing loss can access the auditory
2272    information in the synchronized media content through captions. 2272    information in the synchronized media content through captions.

2444  2444 
2445      Intent of this Success Criterion 2445      Intent of this Success Criterion
2446  2446 
2447The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide people who are blind 2447The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide people who are blind
2448or visually impaired access to the visual information in a synchronized 2448or visually impaired access to the visual information in a synchronized
2449media presentation. The audio description augments the audio portion of 2449media presentation. The audio description augments the audio portion of
2450the presentation with the information needed when the video portion is 2450the presentation with the information needed when the video portion is
2451not available. During existing pauses in dialogue, audio description 2451not available. During existing pauses in dialogue, audio description
2452provides information about actions, characters, scene changes, and 2452provides information about actions, characters, scene changes, and
2453on-screen text that are important and are not described or spoken in the 2453on-screen text that are important and are not described or spoken in the
2454main sound track. 2454main sound track.
2455  2455 
2456/Note 1: / For 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.7, if all of the information in the 2456/Note 1: / For 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.7, if all of the information in the
2457video track is already provided in the audio track, no audio description 2457video track is already provided in the audio track, no audio description
2458is necessary. 2458is necessary.
2459  2459 
2460/Note 2: / 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.8 overlap somewhat with each other. 2460/Note 2: / 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.8 overlap somewhat with each other.
2461This is to give the author some choice at the minimum conformance level, 2461This is to give the author some choice at the minimum conformance level,
2462and to provide additional requirements at higher levels. At Level A in 2462and to provide additional requirements at higher levels. At Level A in
2463Success Criterion 1.2.3, authors do have the choice of providing either 2463Success Criterion 1.2.3, authors do have the choice of providing either
2464an audio description or a full text alternative. If they wish to conform 2464an audio description or a full text alternative. If they wish to conform
2465at Level AA, under Success Criterion 1.2.5 authors must provide an audio 2465at Level AA, under Success Criterion 1.2.5 authors must provide an audio
2466description - a requirement already met if they chose that alternative 2466description - a requirement already met if they chose that alternative
2467for 1.2.3, otherwise an additional requirement. At Level AAA under 2467for 1.2.3, otherwise an additional requirement. At Level AAA under
2468Success Criterion 1.2.8 they must provide an extended text description. 2468Success Criterion 1.2.8 they must provide an extended text description.
2469This is an additional requirement if both 1.2.3 and 1.2.5 were met by 2469This is an additional requirement if both 1.2.3 and 1.2.5 were met by
2470providing an audio description only. If 1.2.3 was met, however, by 2470providing an audio description only. If 1.2.3 was met, however, by
2471providing a text description, and the 1.2.5 requirement for an audio 2471providing a text description, and the 1.2.5 requirement for an audio
2472description was met, then 1.2.8 does not add new requirements. 2472description was met, then 1.2.8 does not add new requirements.

2710    content in synchronized media 2710    content in synchronized media
2711    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#synchronizedmediadef>. 2711    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#synchronizedmediadef>.
2712    (Level AAA) 2712    (Level AAA)
2713  2713 
2714  2714 
2715      Intent of this Success Criterion 2715      Intent of this Success Criterion
2716  2716 
2717The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable people who are deaf or 2717The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable people who are deaf or
2718hard of hearing and who are fluent in a sign language to understand the 2718hard of hearing and who are fluent in a sign language to understand the
2719content of the audio track of synchronized media presentations. Written 2719content of the audio track of synchronized media presentations. Written
2720text, such as that found in captions, is often a second language. 2720text, such as that found in captions, is often a second language.
2721Because sign language provides the ability to provide intonation, 2721Because sign language provides the ability to provide intonation,
2722emotion and other audio information that is reflected in sign language 2722emotion and other audio information that is reflected in sign language
2723interpretation, but not in captions, sign language interpretation 2723interpretation, but not in captions, sign language interpretation
2724provides richer and more equivalent access to synchronized media. People 2724provides richer and more equivalent access to synchronized media. People
2725who communicate extensively in sign language are also faster in sign 2725who communicate extensively in sign language are also faster in sign
2726language and synchronized media is a time-based presentation. 2726language and synchronized media is a time-based presentation.
2727  2727 
2728  2728 
2729        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 1.2.6 2729        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 1.2.6
2730  2730 
2731  * 2731  *
2732  2732 
2733    People whose human language is a sign language sometimes have 2733    People whose human language is a sign language sometimes have
2734    limited reading ability. These individuals may not be able to read 2734    limited reading ability. These individuals may not be able to read
2735    and comprehend the captions and thus require a sign language 2735    and comprehend the captions and thus require a sign language
2736    interpretation to gain access to the synchronized media content. 2736    interpretation to gain access to the synchronized media content.
2737  2737 
2738  2738 
2739      Examples of Success Criterion 1.2.6 2739      Examples of Success Criterion 1.2.6
2740  2740 
2741  * 2741  *
2742  2742 
2743    *Example 1.* A corporation is making an important announcement to 2743    *Example 1.* A corporation is making an important announcement to
2744    all of its employees. The meeting will be held in the main 2744    all of its employees. The meeting will be held in the main
2745    headquarters and streamed to the Web. A sign language interpreter is 2745    headquarters and streamed to the Web. A sign language interpreter is
2746    provided at the meeting location. The live video includes a full 2746    provided at the meeting location. The live video includes a full
2747    view of the sign language interpreter as well as the person presenting. 2747    view of the sign language interpreter as well as the person presenting.
2748  2748 
2749  * 2749  *
2750  2750 
2751    *Example 2.* The same announcement described in example 1 is also 2751    *Example 2.* The same announcement described in example 1 is also
2752    Webcast to remote employees. Since there is only one display 2752    Webcast to remote employees. Since there is only one display
2753    available for this, the sign language interpreter is shown in the 2753    available for this, the sign language interpreter is shown in the
2754    corner of the display. 2754    corner of the display.
2755  2755 
2756  * 2756  *
2757  2757 
2758    *Example 3.* A university is providing an on-line version of a 2758    *Example 3.* A university is providing an on-line version of a
2759    particular lecture by creating a synchronized media presentation of 2759    particular lecture by creating a synchronized media presentation of
2760    the professor delivering the lecture. The presentation includes 2760    the professor delivering the lecture. The presentation includes
2761    video of the professor speaking and demonstrating a science 2761    video of the professor speaking and demonstrating a science
2762    experiment. A sign language interpretation of the lecture is created 2762    experiment. A sign language interpretation of the lecture is created
2763    and presented on the Web with the synchronized media version. 2763    and presented on the Web with the synchronized media version.

2923    Extended Audio Description (Prerecorded):* Where pauses in 2923    Extended Audio Description (Prerecorded):* Where pauses in
2924    foreground audio are insufficient to allow audio descriptions 2924    foreground audio are insufficient to allow audio descriptions
2925    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#audiodescdef> to 2925    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#audiodescdef> to
2926    convey the sense of the video, extended audio description 2926    convey the sense of the video, extended audio description
2927    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#extended-addef> is 2927    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#extended-addef> is
2928    provided for all prerecorded 2928    provided for all prerecorded
2929    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#prerecordeddef> 2929    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#prerecordeddef>
2930    video <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#videodef> 2930    video <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#videodef>
2931    content in synchronized media 2931    content in synchronized media
2932    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#synchronizedmediadef>. 2932    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#synchronizedmediadef>.
2933    (Level AAA) 2933    (Level AAA)
2934  2934 
2935  2935 
2936      Intent of this Success Criterion 2936      Intent of this Success Criterion
2937  2937 
2938The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide people who are blind 2938The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide people who are blind
2939or visually impaired access to a synchronized media presentation beyond 2939or visually impaired access to a synchronized media presentation beyond
2940that which can be provided by standard audio description. This is done 2940that which can be provided by standard audio description. This is done
2941by periodically freezing the synchronized media presentation and playing 2941by periodically freezing the synchronized media presentation and playing
2942additional audio description. The synchronized media presentation is 2942additional audio description. The synchronized media presentation is
2943then resumed. 2943then resumed.
2944  2944 
2945Because it disrupts viewing for those who do not need the additional 2945Because it disrupts viewing for those who do not need the additional
2946description, techniques that allow you to turn the feature on and off 2946description, techniques that allow you to turn the feature on and off
2947are often provided. Alternately, versions with and without the 2947are often provided. Alternately, versions with and without the
2948additional description can be provided. 2948additional description can be provided.
2949  2949 
2950  2950 
2951        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 1.2.7 2951        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 1.2.7
2952  2952 
2953  * 2953  *
2954  2954 
2955    People who are blind, people with low vision who cannot see the 2955    People who are blind, people with low vision who cannot see the
2956    screen, as well as those with cognitive limitations who have 2956    screen, as well as those with cognitive limitations who have
2957    difficulty interpreting visually what is happening, often use audio 2957    difficulty interpreting visually what is happening, often use audio
2958    description of the visual information. However, if there is too much 2958    description of the visual information. However, if there is too much
2959    dialogue the audio description is insufficient. Extended audio 2959    dialogue the audio description is insufficient. Extended audio
2960    description can provide the additional information needed to 2960    description can provide the additional information needed to
2961    understand the video. 2961    understand the video.
2962  2962 
2963  2963 
2964      Examples of Success Criterion 1.2.7 2964      Examples of Success Criterion 1.2.7
2965  2965 
2966  * 2966  *
2967  2967 
2968    /Example 1. Video of a lecture./ A physics professor is giving a 2968    /Example 1. Video of a lecture./ A physics professor is giving a
2969    lecture. He makes freehand sketches on the whiteboard, speaking 2969    lecture. He makes freehand sketches on the whiteboard, speaking
2970    rapidly as he draws. As soon as he has finished discussing one 2970    rapidly as he draws. As soon as he has finished discussing one
2971    problem, he erases the drawing and makes another sketch while 2971    problem, he erases the drawing and makes another sketch while
2972    continuing to speak and gesture with his other hand. The video is 2972    continuing to speak and gesture with his other hand. The video is
2973    paused between problems, and extended audio description of the 2973    paused between problems, and extended audio description of the
2974    professor's drawings and gestures is provided; the video is then 2974    professor's drawings and gestures is provided; the video is then
2975    resumed. 2975    resumed.

3146      Intent of this Success Criterion 3146      Intent of this Success Criterion
3147  3147 
3148The intent of this Success Criterion is to make audio visual material 3148The intent of this Success Criterion is to make audio visual material
3149available to individuals whose vision is too poor to reliably read 3149available to individuals whose vision is too poor to reliably read
3150captions <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#captionsdef> 3150captions <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#captionsdef>
3151and whose hearing is too poor to reliably hear dialogue and audio 3151and whose hearing is too poor to reliably hear dialogue and audio
3152description 3152description
3153<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#audiodescdef>. This is 3153<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#audiodescdef>. This is
3154done by providing an alternative for time-based media. 3154done by providing an alternative for time-based media.
3155  3155 
3156This approach involves providing all of the information in the 3156This approach involves providing all of the information in the
3157synchronized media (both visual and auditory) in text form. An 3157synchronized media (both visual and auditory) in text form. An
3158alternative for time-based media provides a running description of all 3158alternative for time-based media provides a running description of all
3159that is going on in the synchronized media content. The alternative for 3159that is going on in the synchronized media content. The alternative for
3160time-based media reads something like a book. Unlike audio description, 3160time-based media reads something like a book. Unlike audio description,
3161the description of the video portion is not constrained to just the 3161the description of the video portion is not constrained to just the
3162pauses in the existing dialogue. Full descriptions are provided of all 3162pauses in the existing dialogue. Full descriptions are provided of all
3163visual information, including visual context, actions and expressions of 3163visual information, including visual context, actions and expressions of
3164actors, and any other visual material. In addition, non-speech sounds 3164actors, and any other visual material. In addition, non-speech sounds
3165(laughter, off-screen voices, etc.) are described, and transcripts of 3165(laughter, off-screen voices, etc.) are described, and transcripts of
3166all dialogue are included. The sequence of descriptions and dialogue 3166all dialogue are included. The sequence of descriptions and dialogue
3167transcripts is the same as the sequence in the synchronized media 3167transcripts is the same as the sequence in the synchronized media
3168itself. As a result, the alternative for time-based media can provide a 3168itself. As a result, the alternative for time-based media can provide a
3169much more complete representation of the synchronized media content than 3169much more complete representation of the synchronized media content than
3170audio description alone. 3170audio description alone.
3171  3171 
3172If there is any interaction as part of the synchronized media 3172If there is any interaction as part of the synchronized media
3173presentation (e.g., "press now to answer the question") then the 3173presentation (e.g., "press now to answer the question") then the
3174alternative for time-based media would provide hyperlinks or whatever is 3174alternative for time-based media would provide hyperlinks or whatever is
3175needed to provide parallel functionality. 3175needed to provide parallel functionality.
3176  3176 
3177Individuals whose vision is too poor to reliably read captions and whose 3177Individuals whose vision is too poor to reliably read captions and whose
3178hearing is too poor to reliably hear dialogue can access the alternative 3178hearing is too poor to reliably hear dialogue can access the alternative
3179for time-based media by using a refreshable braille display. 3179for time-based media by using a refreshable braille display.
3180  3180 
3181/Note 1: / For 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.7, if all of the information in the 3181/Note 1: / For 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.7, if all of the information in the
3182video track is already provided in the audio track, no audio description 3182video track is already provided in the audio track, no audio description
3183is necessary. 3183is necessary.
3184  3184 
3185/Note 2: / 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.8 overlap somewhat with each other. 3185/Note 2: / 1.2.3, 1.2.5, and 1.2.8 overlap somewhat with each other.
3186This is to give the author some choice at the minimum conformance level, 3186This is to give the author some choice at the minimum conformance level,
3187and to provide additional requirements at higher levels. At Level A in 3187and to provide additional requirements at higher levels. At Level A in
3188Success Criterion 1.2.3, authors do have the choice of providing either 3188Success Criterion 1.2.3, authors do have the choice of providing either
3189an audio description or a full text alternative. If they wish to conform 3189an audio description or a full text alternative. If they wish to conform
3190at Level AA, under Success Criterion 1.2.5 authors must provide an audio 3190at Level AA, under Success Criterion 1.2.5 authors must provide an audio
3191description - a requirement already met if they chose that alternative 3191description - a requirement already met if they chose that alternative
3192for 1.2.3, otherwise an additional requirement. At Level AAA under 3192for 1.2.3, otherwise an additional requirement. At Level AAA under
3193Success Criterion 1.2.8 they must provide an extended text description. 3193Success Criterion 1.2.8 they must provide an extended text description.
3194This is an additional requirement if both 1.2.3 and 1.2.5 were met by 3194This is an additional requirement if both 1.2.3 and 1.2.5 were met by
3195providing an audio description only. If 1.2.3 was met, however, by 3195providing an audio description only. If 1.2.3 was met, however, by
3196providing a text description, and the 1.2.5 requirement for an audio 3196providing a text description, and the 1.2.5 requirement for an audio
3197description was met, then 1.2.8 does not add new requirements. 3197description was met, then 1.2.8 does not add new requirements.

3212    *Example 1. alternative for time-based media for a training video* 3212    *Example 1. alternative for time-based media for a training video*
3213  3213 
3214    A community center purchases a Training video for use by its clients 3214    A community center purchases a Training video for use by its clients
3215    and puts it on the center's intranet. The video involves explaining 3215    and puts it on the center's intranet. The video involves explaining
3216    use of a new technology and has a person talking and showing things 3216    use of a new technology and has a person talking and showing things
3217    at the same time. The community center provides a alternative for 3217    at the same time. The community center provides a alternative for
3218    time-based media that all clients, including those who can neither 3218    time-based media that all clients, including those who can neither
3219    see the demonstrations nor hear the explanations in the synchronized 3219    see the demonstrations nor hear the explanations in the synchronized
3220    media, can use to better understand what is being presented. 3220    media, can use to better understand what is being presented.

3378  3378 
3379  3379 
3380      Intent of this Success Criterion 3380      Intent of this Success Criterion
3381  3381 
3382The intent of this Success Criterion is to make information conveyed by 3382The intent of this Success Criterion is to make information conveyed by
3383live audio, such as video conferencing, live speeches and radio 3383live audio, such as video conferencing, live speeches and radio
3384Webcasts, accessible through the use of a text alternative. A live text 3384Webcasts, accessible through the use of a text alternative. A live text
3385caption service will enable live audio to be accessible to people who 3385caption service will enable live audio to be accessible to people who
3386are deaf or hard of hearing, or who cannot otherwise hear the audio. 3386are deaf or hard of hearing, or who cannot otherwise hear the audio.
3387Such services use a trained human operator who listens in to what is 3387Such services use a trained human operator who listens in to what is
3388being said and uses a special keyboard to enter the text with only a 3388being said and uses a special keyboard to enter the text with only a
3389small delay. They are able to capture a live event with a high degree of 3389small delay. They are able to capture a live event with a high degree of
3390fidelity, and also to insert notes on any non spoken audio which is 3390fidelity, and also to insert notes on any non spoken audio which is
3391essential to understanding the event. A transcript is sometimes a 3391essential to understanding the event. A transcript is sometimes a
3392possibility if the live audio is following a set script; but a live 3392possibility if the live audio is following a set script; but a live
3393caption service is preferred because it plays out at the same pace as 3393caption service is preferred because it plays out at the same pace as
3394the audio itself, and can adapt to any deviations from the script that 3394the audio itself, and can adapt to any deviations from the script that
3395might occur. 3395might occur.
3396  3396 
3397Using untrained operators, or providing a transcript which differs 3397Using untrained operators, or providing a transcript which differs
3398markedly from what actually happens would not be considered meeting this 3398markedly from what actually happens would not be considered meeting this
3399Success Criterion. 3399Success Criterion.
3400  3400

3407    live events; the output from the service is incorporated in a sub 3407    live events; the output from the service is incorporated in a sub
3408    frame of the Web page which includes the streaming audio control. 3408    frame of the Web page which includes the streaming audio control.
3409  3409

3413    the Web. As the actors stick largely to a set script, and the budget 3413    the Web. As the actors stick largely to a set script, and the budget
3414    for the program is small, the producers provide a link (with the 3414    for the program is small, the producers provide a link (with the
3415    playwright's permission) to the script of the play. 3415    playwright's permission) to the script of the play.

3420    accommodate text and graphics, such as Flash or Silverlight. A 3420    accommodate text and graphics, such as Flash or Silverlight. A
3421    stenographer is used to create live captions at an event, and these 3421    stenographer is used to create live captions at an event, and these
3422    are mixed on the fly to produce live captions in the media stream 3422    are mixed on the fly to produce live captions in the media stream
3423    which can be viewed by the media player. 3423    which can be viewed by the media player.

3428    response to a breaking news story, the audio is being recorded and 3428    response to a breaking news story, the audio is being recorded and
3429    streamed over the internet, but due to time constraints a Web 3429    streamed over the internet, but due to time constraints a Web
3430    captioning service cannot be set up in time. As the press release is 3430    captioning service cannot be set up in time. As the press release is
3431    a set statement which the CEO will be reading out, the company 3431    a set statement which the CEO will be reading out, the company
3432    simultaneously provides the transcript of the release. 3432    simultaneously provides the transcript of the release.

3539    for example used in order to give the broadcaster time to queue or 3539    for example used in order to give the broadcaster time to queue or

3551  3551 
3552    *Guideline 1.3: *Create content that can be presented in different 3552    *Guideline 1.3: *Create content that can be presented in different
3553    ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or 3553    ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or
3554    structure. 3554    structure.
3555  3555 
3556  3556 
3557      Intent of Guideline 1.3 3557      Intent of Guideline 1.3
3558  3558 
3559The purpose of this guideline is to ensure that all information is 3559The purpose of this guideline is to ensure that all information is
3560available in a form that can be perceived by all users, for example, 3560available in a form that can be perceived by all users, for example,
3561spoken aloud, or presented in a simpler visual layout. If all of the 3561spoken aloud, or presented in a simpler visual layout. If all of the
3562information is available in a form that can be determined by software, 3562information is available in a form that can be determined by software,
3563then it can be presented to users in different ways (visually, audibly, 3563then it can be presented to users in different ways (visually, audibly,
3564tactilely etc.). If information is embedded in a particular presentation 3564tactilely etc.). If information is embedded in a particular presentation
3565in such a way that the structure and information cannot be 3565in such a way that the structure and information cannot be
3566programmatically determined by the assistive technology, then it cannot 3566programmatically determined by the assistive technology, then it cannot
3567be rendered in other formats as needed by the user. 3567be rendered in other formats as needed by the user.

3570different types of information that are often encoded in presentation 3570different types of information that are often encoded in presentation
3571are also available so that they can be presented in other modalities. 3571are also available so that they can be presented in other modalities.

3602  3602 
3603The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that information and 3603The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that information and
3604relationships that are implied by visual or auditory formatting are 3604relationships that are implied by visual or auditory formatting are
3605preserved when the presentation format changes. For example, the 3605preserved when the presentation format changes. For example, the
3606presentation format changes when the content is read by a screen reader 3606presentation format changes when the content is read by a screen reader
3607or when a user style sheet is substituted for the style sheet provided 3607or when a user style sheet is substituted for the style sheet provided
3608by the author. 3608by the author.

3611are often in a larger, bold font separated from paragraphs by blank 3611are often in a larger, bold font separated from paragraphs by blank
3612lines; list items are preceded by a bullet and perhaps indented; 3612lines; list items are preceded by a bullet and perhaps indented;
3613paragraphs are separated by a blank line; items that share a common 3613paragraphs are separated by a blank line; items that share a common
3614characteristic are organized into tabular rows and columns; form fields 3614characteristic are organized into tabular rows and columns; form fields

3617to each other; words that have special status are indicated by changing 3617to each other; words that have special status are indicated by changing
3618the font family and /or bolding, italicizing, or underlining them and so 3618the font family and /or bolding, italicizing, or underlining them and so
3619on. 3619on.

3641some types of information and relationships. In that case then there 3641some types of information and relationships. In that case then there
3642should be a text description of the information and relationships. For 3642should be a text description of the information and relationships. For

3655determined. The information conveyed by color cannot be adequately 3655determined. The information conveyed by color cannot be adequately
3656presented simply by exposing the value. Therefore, Success Criterion 3656presented simply by exposing the value. Therefore, Success Criterion

3689    fields are displayed in red. In addition, at the end of each label 3689    fields are displayed in red. In addition, at the end of each label
3690    is an asterisk character, *. The instructions for completing the 3690    is an asterisk character, *. The instructions for completing the
