3692    marked with an asterisk *", followed by an example. 3692    marked with an asterisk *", followed by an example.

3702    associated with the appropriate form fields so that assistive 3702    associated with the appropriate form fields so that assistive
3703    technology users can determine the required fields. 3703    technology users can determine the required fields.

4170    *Meaningful Sequence*: 4170    *Meaningful Sequence*:
4171    Understanding SC 1.3.2 4171    Understanding SC 1.3.2
4172  4172 
4173    *1.3.2 4173    *1.3.2
4174    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#content-structure-separation-sequence> 4174    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#content-structure-separation-sequence>
4175    Meaningful Sequence:* When the sequence in which content is 4175    Meaningful Sequence:* When the sequence in which content is
4176    presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence 4176    presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence
4177    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#correct-reading-sequencedef> 4177    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#correct-reading-sequencedef>
4178    can be programmatically determined 4178    can be programmatically determined
4179    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#programmaticallydetermineddef>. 4179    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#programmaticallydetermineddef>.
4180    (Level A) 4180    (Level A)
4181  4181 
4182  4182 
4183      Intent of this Success Criterion 4183      Intent of this Success Criterion
4184  4184 
4185The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable a user agent to 4185The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable a user agent to
4186provide an alternative presentation of content while preserving the 4186provide an alternative presentation of content while preserving the
4187reading order needed to understand the meaning. It is important that it 4187reading order needed to understand the meaning. It is important that it
4188be possible to programmatically determine at least one sequence of the 4188be possible to programmatically determine at least one sequence of the
4189content that makes sense. Content that does not meet this Success 4189content that makes sense. Content that does not meet this Success
4190Criterion may confuse or disorient users when assistive technology reads 4190Criterion may confuse or disorient users when assistive technology reads
4191the content in the wrong order, or when alternate style sheets or other 4191the content in the wrong order, or when alternate style sheets or other
4192formatting changes are applied. 4192formatting changes are applied.
4193  4193 
4194A sequence is /meaningful/ if the order of content in the sequence 4194A sequence is /meaningful/ if the order of content in the sequence
4195cannot be changed without affecting its meaning. For example, if a page 4195cannot be changed without affecting its meaning. For example, if a page
4196contains two independent articles, the relative order of the articles 4196contains two independent articles, the relative order of the articles
4197may not affect their meaning, as long as they are not interleaved. In 4197may not affect their meaning, as long as they are not interleaved. In
4198such a situation, the articles themselves may have meaningful sequence, 4198such a situation, the articles themselves may have meaningful sequence,
4199but the container that contains the articles may not have a meaningful 4199but the container that contains the articles may not have a meaningful
4200sequence. 4200sequence.
4201  4201 
4202The semantics of some elements define whether or not their content is a 4202The semantics of some elements define whether or not their content is a
4203meaningful sequence. For instance, in HTML, text is always a meaningful 4203meaningful sequence. For instance, in HTML, text is always a meaningful
4204sequence. Tables and ordered lists are meaningful sequences, but 4204sequence. Tables and ordered lists are meaningful sequences, but
4205unordered lists are not. 4205unordered lists are not.
4206  4206 
4207The order of content in a sequence is not always meaningful. For 4207The order of content in a sequence is not always meaningful. For
4208example, the relative order of the main section of a Web page and a 4208example, the relative order of the main section of a Web page and a
4209navigation section does not affect their meaning. They could occur in 4209navigation section does not affect their meaning. They could occur in
4210either order in the programmatically determined reading sequence. As 4210either order in the programmatically determined reading sequence. As
4211another example, a magazine article contains several callout sidebars. 4211another example, a magazine article contains several callout sidebars.
4212The order of the article and the sidebars does not affect their meaning. 4212The order of the article and the sidebars does not affect their meaning.
4213In these cases there are a number of different reading orders for a Web 4213In these cases there are a number of different reading orders for a Web
4214page that can satisfy the Success Criterion. 4214page that can satisfy the Success Criterion.

4422  4422 
4423      Intent of this Success Criterion 4423      Intent of this Success Criterion
4424  4424 
4425The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that all users can 4425The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that all users can
4426access instructions for using the content, even when they cannot 4426access instructions for using the content, even when they cannot
4427perceive shape or size or use information about spatial location or 4427perceive shape or size or use information about spatial location or
4428orientation. Some content relies on knowledge of the shape or position 4428orientation. Some content relies on knowledge of the shape or position
4429of objects that are not available from the structure of the content (for 4429of objects that are not available from the structure of the content (for
4430example, "round button" or "button to the right"). Some users with 4430example, "round button" or "button to the right"). Some users with
4431disabilities are not able to perceive shape or position due to the 4431disabilities are not able to perceive shape or position due to the
4432nature of the assistive technologies they use. This Success Criterion 4432nature of the assistive technologies they use. This Success Criterion
4433requires that additional information be provided to clarify anything 4433requires that additional information be provided to clarify anything
4434that is dependent on this kind of information. 4434that is dependent on this kind of information.
4435  4435 
4436Providing information using shape and/or location, however, is an 4436Providing information using shape and/or location, however, is an
4437effective method for many users including those with cognitive 4437effective method for many users including those with cognitive
4438limitations. This provision should not discourage those types of cues as 4438limitations. This provision should not discourage those types of cues as
4439long as the information is also provided in other ways. 4439long as the information is also provided in other ways.
4440  4440 
4441In some languages, it is commonly understood that "above" refers to the 4441In some languages, it is commonly understood that "above" refers to the
4442content previous to that point in the content and "below" refers to the 4442content previous to that point in the content and "below" refers to the
4443content after that point. In such languages, if the content being 4443content after that point. In such languages, if the content being
4444referenced is in the appropriate place in the reading order and the 4444referenced is in the appropriate place in the reading order and the
4445references are unambiguous, statements such as "choose one of the links 4445references are unambiguous, statements such as "choose one of the links
4446below" or "all of the above" would conform to this Success Criterion. 4446below" or "all of the above" would conform to this Success Criterion.

4452  4452 
4453    People who are blind and people who have low vision may not be able 4453    People who are blind and people who have low vision may not be able
4454    to understand information if it is conveyed by shape and/or 4454    to understand information if it is conveyed by shape and/or
4455    location. Providing additional information other than shape and/or 4455    location. Providing additional information other than shape and/or
4456    location will allow them to understand the information conveyed by 4456    location will allow them to understand the information conveyed by
4457    shape and/or alone. 4457    shape and/or alone.

4469    time of a particular event has a specific background color and 4469    time of a particular event has a specific background color and
4470    diamond shaped glyph so it can be identified by color and shape. 4470    diamond shaped glyph so it can be identified by color and shape.

4476    An on-line multi-page survey uses a link implemented as a green 4476    An on-line multi-page survey uses a link implemented as a green
4477    arrow icon placed in the lower right hand corner of the content to 4477    arrow icon placed in the lower right hand corner of the content to
4478    move from one survey page to the next. The arrow is clearly labeled 4478    move from one survey page to the next. The arrow is clearly labeled
4479    with "Next" and the instructions state, "To move to the next section 4479    with "Next" and the instructions state, "To move to the next section
4480    of the survey, select the green arrow icon labeled 'Next' in the 4480    of the survey, select the green arrow icon labeled 'Next' in the
4481    lower right corner below the last survey question." This example 4481    lower right corner below the last survey question." This example
4482    uses both positioning, color and labeling to help identify the icon. 4482    uses both positioning, color and labeling to help identify the icon.

4546    *Distinguishable*: 4546    *Distinguishable*:
4547    Understanding Guideline 1.4 4547    Understanding Guideline 1.4
4548  4548 
4549    *Guideline 1.4: * Make it easier for users to see and hear content 4549    *Guideline 1.4: * Make it easier for users to see and hear content
4550    including separating foreground from background. 4550    including separating foreground from background.
4551  4551 
4552  4552 
4553      Intent of Guideline 1.4 4553      Intent of Guideline 1.4
4554  4554 
4555While some guidelines are focused on making information available in a 4555While some guidelines are focused on making information available in a
4556form that can be presented in alternate formats, this guideline is 4556form that can be presented in alternate formats, this guideline is
4557concerned with making the default presentation as easy to perceive as 4557concerned with making the default presentation as easy to perceive as
4558possible to people with disabilities. The primary focus is on making it 4558possible to people with disabilities. The primary focus is on making it
4559easier for users to separate foreground information from the background. 4559easier for users to separate foreground information from the background.
4560For visual presentations this involves making sure that information 4560For visual presentations this involves making sure that information
4561presented on top of a background contrasts sufficiently with the 4561presented on top of a background contrasts sufficiently with the
4562background. For audio presentations this involves making sure that 4562background. For audio presentations this involves making sure that
4563foreground sounds are sufficiently louder than the background sounds. 4563foreground sounds are sufficiently louder than the background sounds.
4564Individuals with visual and hearing disabilities have much greater 4564Individuals with visual and hearing disabilities have much greater
4565difficulty separating foreground and background information. 4565difficulty separating foreground and background information.
4566  4566 
4567  4567 
4568      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 1.4 (not success criteria specific) 4568      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 1.4 (not success criteria specific)
4569  4569 
4570Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this 4570Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this
4571guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success 4571guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success
4572Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for 4572Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for
4573addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success 4573addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success
4574criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or 4574criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or
4575sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types 4575sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types
4576of Web content more accessible to more people. 4576of Web content more accessible to more people.

4593    *Use of Color*: 4593    *Use of Color*:
4594    Understanding SC 1.4.1 4594    Understanding SC 1.4.1
4595  4595 
4596    *1.4.1 4596    *1.4.1
4597    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#visual-audio-contrast-without-color> 4597    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#visual-audio-contrast-without-color>
4598    Use of Color:* Color is not used as the only visual means of 4598    Use of Color:* Color is not used as the only visual means of
4599    conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, 4599    conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response,
4600    or distinguishing a visual element. (Level A) 4600    or distinguishing a visual element. (Level A)
4601  4601 
4602    /Note: /This success criterion addresses color perception 4602    /Note: /This success criterion addresses color perception
4603    specifically. Other forms of perception are covered in /Guideline 4603    specifically. Other forms of perception are covered in /Guideline
4604    1.3 <#content-structure-separation>/ including programmatic access 4604    1.3 <#content-structure-separation>/ including programmatic access
4605    to color and other visual presentation coding. 4605    to color and other visual presentation coding.
4606  4606 
4607  4607 
4608      Intent of this Success Criterion 4608      Intent of this Success Criterion
4609  4609 
4610The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that all users can 4610The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that all users can
4611access information that is conveyed by color differences, that is, by 4611access information that is conveyed by color differences, that is, by
4612the use of color where each color has a meaning assigned to it. If the 4612the use of color where each color has a meaning assigned to it. If the
4613information is conveyed through color differences in an image (or other 4613information is conveyed through color differences in an image (or other
4614non-text format), the color may not be seen by users with color 4614non-text format), the color may not be seen by users with color
4615deficiencies. In this case, providing the information conveyed with 4615deficiencies. In this case, providing the information conveyed with
4616color through another visual means ensures users who cannot see color 4616color through another visual means ensures users who cannot see color
4617can still perceive the information. 4617can still perceive the information.
4618  4618 
4619Color is an important asset in design of Web content, enhancing its 4619Color is an important asset in design of Web content, enhancing its
4620aesthetic appeal, its usability, and its accessibility. However, some 4620aesthetic appeal, its usability, and its accessibility. However, some
4621users have difficulty perceiving color. People with partial sight often 4621users have difficulty perceiving color. People with partial sight often
4622experience limited color vision, and many older users do not see color 4622experience limited color vision, and many older users do not see color
4623well. In addition, people using text-only, limited-color or monochrome 4623well. In addition, people using text-only, limited-color or monochrome
4624displays and browsers will be unable to access information that is 4624displays and browsers will be unable to access information that is
4625presented only in color. 4625presented only in color.
4626  4626 
4627Examples of information conveyed by color differences: required fields 4627Examples of information conveyed by color differences: required fields
4628are red", error is shown in red", and Mary's sales are in red, Tom's 4628are red", error is shown in red", and Mary's sales are in red, Tom's
4629are in blue". Examples of indications of an action include: using color 4629are in blue". Examples of indications of an action include: using color
4630to indicate that a link will open in a new window or that a database 4630to indicate that a link will open in a new window or that a database
4631entry has been updated successfully. An example of prompting a response 4631entry has been updated successfully. An example of prompting a response
4632would be: using highlighting on form fields to indicate that a required 4632would be: using highlighting on form fields to indicate that a required
4633field had been left blank. 4633field had been left blank.
4634  4634 
4635/Note: /This should not in any way discourage the use of color on a 4635/Note: /This should not in any way discourage the use of color on a
4636page, or even color coding if it is redundant with other visual indication. 4636page, or even color coding if it is redundant with other visual indication.

4652    color is available in other visual ways. 4652    color is available in other visual ways.

4670      Examples of Success Criterion 1.4.1 4670      Examples of Success Criterion 1.4.1

4673  4673 
4674    *A form that uses color and text to indicate required fields* 4674    *A form that uses color and text to indicate required fields*
4675  4675 
4676    A form contains both required and optional fields. Instructions at 4676    A form contains both required and optional fields. Instructions at
4677    the top of the form explain that required fields are labeled with 4677    the top of the form explain that required fields are labeled with
4678    red text and also with an icon whose text alternative says, 4678    red text and also with an icon whose text alternative says,
4679    "Required." Both the red text and the icon are programmatically 4679    "Required." Both the red text and the icon are programmatically
4680    associated with the appropriate form fields so that assistive 4680    associated with the appropriate form fields so that assistive
4681    technology users can determine the required fields. 4681    technology users can determine the required fields.
4682  4682 
4683  * 4683  *
4684  4684 
4685    *An examination.* 4685    *An examination.*
4686  4686 
4687    Students view an SVG image of a chemical compound and identify the 4687    Students view an SVG image of a chemical compound and identify the
4688    chemical elements present based on the colors and numbers used in 4688    chemical elements present based on the colors and numbers used in
4689    the diagram. The text alternatives associated with each element name 4689    the diagram. The text alternatives associated with each element name
4690    the color of the element and indicate the element's position in the 4690    the color of the element and indicate the element's position in the
4691    diagram. Students who cannot perceive color have the same 4691    diagram. Students who cannot perceive color have the same
4692    information about the compound as their classmates. (This technique 4692    information about the compound as their classmates. (This technique
4693    also satisfies Guideline 1.1 4693    also satisfies Guideline 1.1
4694    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#text-equiv-all> 4694    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#text-equiv-all>
4695    Level A.) 4695    Level A.)

4699    *Disabled Form elements.* 4699    *Disabled Form elements.*
4700  4700 
4701    Form elements which are disabled via markup or scripting, are greyed 4701    Form elements which are disabled via markup or scripting, are greyed
4702    out and made inactive by the user agent. When in the disabled state 4702    out and made inactive by the user agent. When in the disabled state
4703    these elements do not receive focus. Assistive technologies can 4703    these elements do not receive focus. Assistive technologies can
4704    programmatically determine the state of disabled elements and will 4704    programmatically determine the state of disabled elements and will
4705    provide this information to the user as the elements are encountered 4705    provide this information to the user as the elements are encountered
4706    on the page. The change in color and loss of focus provides 4706    on the page. The change in color and loss of focus provides
4707    redundant, visual information about the state of the control. 4707    redundant, visual information about the state of the control.

4881    *Audio Control*: 4881    *Audio Control*:
4882    Understanding SC 1.4.2 4882    Understanding SC 1.4.2

4885    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#visual-audio-contrast-dis-audio> 4885    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#visual-audio-contrast-dis-audio>
4886    Audio Control:* If any audio on a Web page plays automatically for 4886    Audio Control:* If any audio on a Web page plays automatically for
4887    more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism 4887    more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism
4888    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#mechanismdef> is 4888    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#mechanismdef> is
4889    available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to 4889    available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to
4890    control audio volume independently from the overall system volume 4890    control audio volume independently from the overall system volume
4891    level. (Level A) 4891    level. (Level A)
4892  4892 
4893    /Note: /Since any content that does not meet this success criterion 4893    /Note: /Since any content that does not meet this success criterion
4894    can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all 4894    can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all
4895    content on the Web page (whether or not it is used to meet other 4895    content on the Web page (whether or not it is used to meet other
4896    success criteria) must meet this success criterion. See /Conformance 4896    success criteria) must meet this success criterion. See /Conformance
4897    Requirement 5: Non-Interference 4897    Requirement 5: Non-Interference
4898    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#cc5>/. 4898    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#cc5>/.
4899  4899 
4900  4900 
4901      Intent of this Success Criterion 4901      Intent of this Success Criterion
4902  4902 
4903Individuals who use screen reading software can find it hard to hear the 4903Individuals who use screen reading software can find it hard to hear the
4904speech output if there is other audio playing at the same time. This 4904speech output if there is other audio playing at the same time. This
4905difficulty is exacerbated when the screen reader's speech output is 4905difficulty is exacerbated when the screen reader's speech output is
4906software based (as most are today) and is controlled via the same volume 4906software based (as most are today) and is controlled via the same volume
4907control as the sound. Therefore, it is important that the user be able 4907control as the sound. Therefore, it is important that the user be able
4908to turn off the background sound. Note: Having control of the volume 4908to turn off the background sound. Note: Having control of the volume
4909includes being able to reduce its volume to zero. 4909includes being able to reduce its volume to zero.
4910  4910 
4911/Note: /Playing audio automatically when landing on a page may affect a 4911/Note: /Playing audio automatically when landing on a page may affect a
4912screen reader user's ability to find the mechanism to stop it because 4912screen reader user's ability to find the mechanism to stop it because
4913they navigate by listening and automatically started sounds might 4913they navigate by listening and automatically started sounds might
4914interfere with that navigation. Therefore, we discourage the practice of 4914interfere with that navigation. Therefore, we discourage the practice of
4915automatically starting sounds (especially if they last more than 3 4915automatically starting sounds (especially if they last more than 3
4916seconds), and encourage that the sound be /started/ by an action 4916seconds), and encourage that the sound be /started/ by an action
4917initiated by the user after they reach the page, rather than requiring 4917initiated by the user after they reach the page, rather than requiring
4918that the sound be /stopped/ by an action of the user after they land on 4918that the sound be /stopped/ by an action of the user after they land on
4919the page. 4919the page.
4920  4920 
4921See also /Understanding Success Criterion 1.4.7 Low or No Background 4921See also /Understanding Success Criterion 1.4.7 Low or No Background
4922Audio <#visual-audio-contrast-noaudio>/. 4922Audio <#visual-audio-contrast-noaudio>/.

4926  4926 
4927  * 4927  *
4928  4928 
4929    Individuals who use screen reading technologies can hear the screen 4929    Individuals who use screen reading technologies can hear the screen
4930    reader without other sounds playing. This is especially important 4930    reader without other sounds playing. This is especially important
4931    for those who are hard of hearing and for those whose screen readers 4931    for those who are hard of hearing and for those whose screen readers
4932    use the system volume (so they cannot turn sound down and screen 4932    use the system volume (so they cannot turn sound down and screen
4933    reader up). 4933    reader up).
4934  4934

4938    focusing on visual content (including text) when audio is playing. 4938    focusing on visual content (including text) when audio is playing.

4945    An audio file begins playing automatically when a page is opened. 4945    An audio file begins playing automatically when a page is opened.
4946    However, the audio can be stopped by the user by selecting a 4946    However, the audio can be stopped by the user by selecting a
4947    "silent" link at the top of the page. 4947    "silent" link at the top of the page.

4952    than 3 seconds. 4952    than 3 seconds.

4957    control at the top that allows users to turn the sound off. 4957    control at the top that allows users to turn the sound off.

5074    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#textdef> and images 5074    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#textdef> and images

5096        that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast 5096        that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast
5097        requirement. 5097        requirement.
5098  5098 
5099      * 5099      *
5100  5100 
5101        *Logotypes: * Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no 5101        *Logotypes: * Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no
5102        minimum contrast requirement. 5102        minimum contrast requirement.
5103  5103 
5104  5104 
5105      Intent of this Success Criterion 5105      Intent of this Success Criterion
5106  5106 
5107The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide enough contrast 5107The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide enough contrast
5108between text and its background so that it can be read by people with 5108between text and its background so that it can be read by people with
5109moderately low vision (who do not use contrast-enhancing assistive 5109moderately low vision (who do not use contrast-enhancing assistive
5110technology). For people without color deficiencies, hue and saturation 5110technology). For people without color deficiencies, hue and saturation
5111have minimal or no effect on legibility as assessed by reading 5111have minimal or no effect on legibility as assessed by reading
5112performance (Knoblauch et al., 1991). Color deficiencies can affect 5112performance (Knoblauch et al., 1991). Color deficiencies can affect
5113luminance contrast somewhat. Therefore, in the recommendation, the 5113luminance contrast somewhat. Therefore, in the recommendation, the
5114contrast is calculated in such a way that color is not a key factor so 5114contrast is calculated in such a way that color is not a key factor so
5115that people who have a color vision deficit will also have adequate 5115that people who have a color vision deficit will also have adequate
5116contrast between the text and the background. 5116contrast between the text and the background.
5117  5117 
5118Text that is decorative and conveys no information is excluded. For 5118Text that is decorative and conveys no information is excluded. For
5119example, if random words are used to create a background and the words 5119example, if random words are used to create a background and the words
5120could be rearranged or substituted without changing meaning, then it 5120could be rearranged or substituted without changing meaning, then it
5121would be decorative and would not need to meet this criterion. 5121would be decorative and would not need to meet this criterion.
5122  5122 
5123Text that is larger and has wider character strokes is easier to read at 5123Text that is larger and has wider character strokes is easier to read at
5124lower contrast. The contrast requirement for larger text is therefore 5124lower contrast. The contrast requirement for larger text is therefore
5125lower. This allows authors to use a wider range of color choices for 5125lower. This allows authors to use a wider range of color choices for
5126large text, which is helpful for design of pages, particularly titles. 5126large text, which is helpful for design of pages, particularly titles.
512718 point text or 14 point bold text is judged to be large enough to 512718 point text or 14 point bold text is judged to be large enough to
5128require a lower contrast ratio. (See The American Printing House for the 5128require a lower contrast ratio. (See The American Printing House for the
5129Blind Guidelines for Large Printing and The Library of Congress 5129Blind Guidelines for Large Printing and The Library of Congress
5130Guidelines for Large Print under Resources 5130Guidelines for Large Print under Resources
5131<#visual-audio-contrast-contrast-resources-head>). "18 point" and "bold" 5131<#visual-audio-contrast-contrast-resources-head>). "18 point" and "bold"
5132can both have different meanings in different fonts but, except for very 5132can both have different meanings in different fonts but, except for very
5133thin or unusual fonts, they should be sufficient. Since there are so 5133thin or unusual fonts, they should be sufficient. Since there are so
5134many different fonts, the general measures are used and a note regarding 5134many different fonts, the general measures are used and a note regarding
5135fancy or thin fonts is included. 5135fancy or thin fonts is included.
5136  5136 
5137/Note: /Because different image editing applications default to 5137/Note: /Because different image editing applications default to
5138different pixel densities (e.g. 72 PPI or 96 PPI), specifying point 5138different pixel densities (e.g. 72 PPI or 96 PPI), specifying point
5139sizes for fonts from within an image editing application can be 5139sizes for fonts from within an image editing application can be
5140unreliable when it comes to presenting text at a specific size. When 5140unreliable when it comes to presenting text at a specific size. When
5141creating images of large-scale text, authors should ensure that the text 5141creating images of large-scale text, authors should ensure that the text
5142in the resulting image is roughly equivalent to 1.2 and 1.5 em or to 5142in the resulting image is roughly equivalent to 1.2 and 1.5 em or to
5143120% or 150% of the default size for body text. For example, for a 72 5143120% or 150% of the default size for body text. For example, for a 72
5144PPI image, an author would need to use approximately 19 pt and 24 pt 5144PPI image, an author would need to use approximately 19 pt and 24 pt
5145font sizes in order to successfully present images of large-scale text 5145font sizes in order to successfully present images of large-scale text
5146to a user. 5146to a user.
5147  5147 
5148The previously-mentioned contrast requirements for text also apply to 5148The previously-mentioned contrast requirements for text also apply to
5149images of text (text that has been rendered into pixels and then stored 5149images of text (text that has been rendered into pixels and then stored
5150in an image format) as stated in Success Criterion 1.4.3. 5150in an image format) as stated in Success Criterion 1.4.3.
5151  5151 
5152This requirement applies to situations in which images of text were 5152This requirement applies to situations in which images of text were
5153intended to be understood as text. Incidental text, such as in 5153intended to be understood as text. Incidental text, such as in
5154photographs that happen to include a street sign, are not included. Nor 5154photographs that happen to include a street sign, are not included. Nor
5155is text that for some reason is designed to be invisible to all viewers. 5155is text that for some reason is designed to be invisible to all viewers.
5156Stylized text, such as in corporate logos, should be treated in terms of 5156Stylized text, such as in corporate logos, should be treated in terms of
5157its function on the page, which may or may not warrant including the 5157its function on the page, which may or may not warrant including the
5158content in the text alternative. Corporate visual guidelines beyond logo 5158content in the text alternative. Corporate visual guidelines beyond logo
5159and logotype are not included in the exception. 5159and logotype are not included in the exception.

5162picture that contains significant other visual content,". This exception 5162picture that contains significant other visual content,". This exception
5163is intended to separate pictures that have text in them from images of 5163is intended to separate pictures that have text in them from images of
5164text that are done to replace text in order to get a particular look. 5164text that are done to replace text in order to get a particular look.
5165  5165 
5166/Note 1: /Some people with cognitive disabilities require color 5166/Note 1: /Some people with cognitive disabilities require color
5167combinations or hues that have low contrast, and therefore we allow and 5167combinations or hues that have low contrast, and therefore we allow and
5168encourage authors to provide mechanisms to adjust the foreground and 5168encourage authors to provide mechanisms to adjust the foreground and
5169background colors of the content. Some of the combinations that could be 5169background colors of the content. Some of the combinations that could be
5170chosen may have contrast levels that will be lower than those found in 5170chosen may have contrast levels that will be lower than those found in
5171the Success Criteria. This is not a violation of this Success Criteria 5171the Success Criteria. This is not a violation of this Success Criteria
5172provided there is a mechanism that will return to the default values set 5172provided there is a mechanism that will return to the default values set
5173out in the Success Criteria. 5173out in the Success Criteria.

5175/Note 2: /Images of text do not scale as well as text because they tend 5175/Note 2: /Images of text do not scale as well as text because they tend
5176to pixelate. It is also harder to change foreground and background 5176to pixelate. It is also harder to change foreground and background
5177contrast and color combinations for images of text, which is necessary 5177contrast and color combinations for images of text, which is necessary
5178for some users. Therefore, we suggest using text wherever possible, and 5178for some users. Therefore, we suggest using text wherever possible, and
5179when not, consider supplying an image of higher resolution. 5179when not, consider supplying an image of higher resolution.

5183also be provided for data presented in these forms. 5183also be provided for data presented in these forms.

5188  5188 
5189        Rationale for the Ratios Chosen 5189        Rationale for the Ratios Chosen
5190  5190 
5191A contrast ratio of 3:1 is the minimum level recommended by [ISO-9241-3] 5191A contrast ratio of 3:1 is the minimum level recommended by [ISO-9241-3]
5192<#ISO-9241-3> and [ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> for 5192<#ISO-9241-3> and [ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> for
5193standard text and vision. The 4.5:1 ratio is used in this provision to 5193standard text and vision. The 4.5:1 ratio is used in this provision to
5194account for the loss in contrast that results from moderately low visual 5194account for the loss in contrast that results from moderately low visual
5195acuity, congenital or acquired color deficiencies, or the loss of 5195acuity, congenital or acquired color deficiencies, or the loss of
5196contrast sensitivity that typically accompanies aging. 5196contrast sensitivity that typically accompanies aging.
5197  5197 
5198The rationale is based on a) adoption of the 3:1 contrast ratio for 5198The rationale is based on a) adoption of the 3:1 contrast ratio for
5199minimum acceptable contrast for normal observers, in the ANSI standard, 5199minimum acceptable contrast for normal observers, in the ANSI standard,
5200and b) the empirical finding that in the population, visual acuity of 5200and b) the empirical finding that in the population, visual acuity of
520120/40 is associated with a contrast sensitivity loss of roughly 1.5 520120/40 is associated with a contrast sensitivity loss of roughly 1.5
5202[ARDITI-FAYE] <#ARDITI-FAYE>. A user with 20/40 would thus require a 5202[ARDITI-FAYE] <#ARDITI-FAYE>. A user with 20/40 would thus require a
5203contrast ratio of 3 * 1.5 = 4.5 to 1. Following analogous empirical 5203contrast ratio of 3 * 1.5 = 4.5 to 1. Following analogous empirical
5204findings and the same logic, the user with 20/80 visual acuity would 5204findings and the same logic, the user with 20/80 visual acuity would
5205require contrast of about 7:1. 5205require contrast of about 7:1.
5206  5206 
5207Hues are perceived differently by users with color vision deficiencies 5207Hues are perceived differently by users with color vision deficiencies
5208(both congenital and acquired) resulting in different colors and 5208(both congenital and acquired) resulting in different colors and
5209relative luminance contrasts than for normally sighted users. Because of 5209relative luminance contrasts than for normally sighted users. Because of
5210this, effective contrast and readability are different for this 5210this, effective contrast and readability are different for this
5211population. However, color deficiencies are so diverse that prescribing 5211population. However, color deficiencies are so diverse that prescribing
5212effective general use color pairs (for contrast) based on quantitative 5212effective general use color pairs (for contrast) based on quantitative
5213data is not feasible. Requiring good luminance contrast accommodates 5213data is not feasible. Requiring good luminance contrast accommodates
5214this by requiring contrast that is independent of color perception. 5214this by requiring contrast that is independent of color perception.
5215Fortunately, most of the luminance contribution is from the mid and long 5215Fortunately, most of the luminance contribution is from the mid and long
5216wave receptors which largely overlap in their spectral responses. The 5216wave receptors which largely overlap in their spectral responses. The
5217result is that effective luminance contrast can generally be computed 5217result is that effective luminance contrast can generally be computed
5218without regard to specific color deficiency, except for the use of 5218without regard to specific color deficiency, except for the use of
5219predominantly long wavelength colors against darker colors (generally 5219predominantly long wavelength colors against darker colors (generally
5220appearing black) for those who have protanopia. (We provide an advisory 5220appearing black) for those who have protanopia. (We provide an advisory
5221technique on avoiding red on black for that reason). For more 5221technique on avoiding red on black for that reason). For more
5222information see [ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH] <#ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1994> 5222information see [ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH] <#ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1994>
5223[ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1996] <#ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1996> [ARDITI] <#ARDITI>. 5223[ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1996] <#ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1996> [ARDITI] <#ARDITI>.
5224  5224 
5225The contrast ratio of 4.5:1 was chosen for level AA because it 5225The contrast ratio of 4.5:1 was chosen for level AA because it
5226compensated for the loss in contrast sensitivity usually experienced by 5226compensated for the loss in contrast sensitivity usually experienced by
5227users with vision loss equivalent to approximately 20/40 vision. (20/40 5227users with vision loss equivalent to approximately 20/40 vision. (20/40
5228calculates to approximately 4.5:1.) 20/40 is commonly reported as 5228calculates to approximately 4.5:1.) 20/40 is commonly reported as
5229typical visual acuity of elders at roughly age 80. [GITTINGS-FOZARD] 5229typical visual acuity of elders at roughly age 80. [GITTINGS-FOZARD]
5230<#GITTINGS-FOZARD> 5230<#GITTINGS-FOZARD>
5231  5231 
5232The contrast ratio of 7:1 was chosen for level AAA because it 5232The contrast ratio of 7:1 was chosen for level AAA because it
5233compensated for the loss in contrast sensitivity usually experienced by 5233compensated for the loss in contrast sensitivity usually experienced by
5234users with vision loss equivalent to approximately 20/80 vision. People 5234users with vision loss equivalent to approximately 20/80 vision. People
5235with more than this degree of vision loss usually use assistive 5235with more than this degree of vision loss usually use assistive
5236technologies to access their content (and the assistive technologies 5236technologies to access their content (and the assistive technologies
5237usually have contrast enhancing, as well as magnification capability 5237usually have contrast enhancing, as well as magnification capability
5238built into them). The 7:1 level therefore generally provides 5238built into them). The 7:1 level therefore generally provides
5239compensation for the loss in contrast sensitivity experienced by users 5239compensation for the loss in contrast sensitivity experienced by users
5240with low vision who do not use assistive technology and provides 5240with low vision who do not use assistive technology and provides
5241contrast enhancement for color deficiency as well. 5241contrast enhancement for color deficiency as well.

5244[ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> are for body text. A relaxed 5244[ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> are for body text. A relaxed
5245contrast ratio is provided for text that is much larger. 5245contrast ratio is provided for text that is much larger.

5252for the Internet - sRGB" [sRGB] <#sRGB>. 5252for the Internet - sRGB" [sRGB] <#sRGB>.

5255and [ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> standards. 5255and [ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> standards.

5258light to be included in the calculation of L1 and L2. The .05 value used 5258light to be included in the calculation of L1 and L2. The .05 value used
5259is based on Typical Viewing Flare from [IEC-4WD] <#IEC-4WD> and the 5259is based on Typical Viewing Flare from [IEC-4WD] <#IEC-4WD> and the
5260[sRGB] <#sRGB> paper by M. Stokes et al. 5260[sRGB] <#sRGB> paper by M. Stokes et al.

5262This Success Criterion and its definitions use the terms "contrast 5262This Success Criterion and its definitions use the terms "contrast
5263ratio" and "relative luminance" rather than "luminance" to reflect the 5263ratio" and "relative luminance" rather than "luminance" to reflect the
5264fact that Web content does not emit light itself. The contrast ratio 5264fact that Web content does not emit light itself. The contrast ratio
5265gives a measure of the relative luminance that would result when 5265gives a measure of the relative luminance that would result when
5266displayed. (Because it is a ratio, it is dimensionless.) 5266displayed. (Because it is a ratio, it is dimensionless.)

5288    People with low vision often have difficulty reading text that does 5288    People with low vision often have difficulty reading text that does
5289    not contrast with its background. This can be exacerbated if the 5289    not contrast with its background. This can be exacerbated if the
5290    person has a color vision deficiency that lowers the contrast even 5290    person has a color vision deficiency that lowers the contrast even
5291    further. Providing a minimum luminance contrast ratio between the 5291    further. Providing a minimum luminance contrast ratio between the
5292    text and its background can make the text more readable even if the 5292    text and its background can make the text more readable even if the
5293    person does not see the full range of colors. It also works for the 5293    person does not see the full range of colors. It also works for the
5294    rare individuals who see no color. 5294    rare individuals who see no color.

5682  5682 
5683      Intent of this Success Criterion 5683      Intent of this Success Criterion
5684  5684 
5685The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that visually rendered 5685The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that visually rendered
5686text, including text-based controls (text characters that have been 5686text, including text-based controls (text characters that have been
5687displayed so that they can be seen [vs. text characters that are still 5687displayed so that they can be seen [vs. text characters that are still
5688in data form such as ASCII]) can be scaled successfully so that it can 5688in data form such as ASCII]) can be scaled successfully so that it can
5689be read directly by people with mild visual disabilities, without 5689be read directly by people with mild visual disabilities, without
5690requiring the use of assistive technology such as a screen magnifier. 5690requiring the use of assistive technology such as a screen magnifier.
5691Users may benefit from scaling all content on the Web page, but text is 5691Users may benefit from scaling all content on the Web page, but text is
5692most critical. 5692most critical.
5693  5693 
5694The scaling of content is primarily a user agent responsibility. User 5694The scaling of content is primarily a user agent responsibility. User
5695agents that satisfy UAAG 1.0 Checkpoint 4.1 5695agents that satisfy UAAG 1.0 Checkpoint 4.1
5696<http://www.w3.org/TR/WAI-USERAGENT/guidelines.html#tech-configure-text-scale> 5696<http://www.w3.org/TR/WAI-USERAGENT/guidelines.html#tech-configure-text-scale>
5697allow users to configure text scale. The author's responsibility is to 5697allow users to configure text scale. The author's responsibility is to
5698create Web content that does not prevent the user agent from scaling the 5698create Web content that does not prevent the user agent from scaling the
5699content effectively. Authors may satisfy this Success Criterion by 5699content effectively. Authors may satisfy this Success Criterion by
5700verifying that content does not interfere with user agent support for 5700verifying that content does not interfere with user agent support for
5701resizing text, including text-based controls, or by providing direct 5701resizing text, including text-based controls, or by providing direct
5702support for resizing text or changing the layout. An example of direct 5702support for resizing text or changing the layout. An example of direct
5703support might be via server-side script that can be used to assign 5703support might be via server-side script that can be used to assign
5704different style sheets. 5704different style sheets.
5705  5705 
5706The author cannot rely on the user agent to satisfy this Success 5706The author cannot rely on the user agent to satisfy this Success
5707Criterion for HTML content if users do not have access to a user agent 5707Criterion for HTML content if users do not have access to a user agent
5708with zoom support. For example, if they work in an environment that 5708with zoom support. For example, if they work in an environment that
5709requires them to use IE 6 or Firefox. 5709requires them to use IE 6 or Firefox.
5710  5710 
5711If the author is using a technology whose user agents do not provide 5711If the author is using a technology whose user agents do not provide
5712zoom support, the author is responsible to provide this type of 5712zoom support, the author is responsible to provide this type of
5713functionality directly or to provide content that works with the type of 5713functionality directly or to provide content that works with the type of
5714functionality provided by the user agent. If the user agent doesn't 5714functionality provided by the user agent. If the user agent doesn't
5715provide zoom functionality but does let the the user change the text 5715provide zoom functionality but does let the the user change the text
5716size, the author is responsible for ensuring that the content remains 5716size, the author is responsible for ensuring that the content remains
5717usable when the text is resized. 5717usable when the text is resized.
5718  5718 
5719Some user interface components that function as a label and require 5719Some user interface components that function as a label and require
5720activation by the user to access content are not wide enough to 5720activation by the user to access content are not wide enough to
5721accommodate the label's content. For example, in Web mail applications 5721accommodate the label's content. For example, in Web mail applications
5722the subject column may not wide enough to accommodate every possible 5722the subject column may not wide enough to accommodate every possible
5723subject header, but activating the subject header takes the user to the 5723subject header, but activating the subject header takes the user to the
5724full message with the full subject header. In Web-based spreadsheets, 5724full message with the full subject header. In Web-based spreadsheets,
5725cell content that is too long to be displayed in a column can be 5725cell content that is too long to be displayed in a column can be
5726truncated, and the full content of the cell is available to the user 5726truncated, and the full content of the cell is available to the user
5727when the cell receives focus. The content of a user interface component 5727when the cell receives focus. The content of a user interface component
5728may also become too wide in user interfaces where the user can resize 5728may also become too wide in user interfaces where the user can resize
5729the column width. In this type of user interface component, line 5729the column width. In this type of user interface component, line
5730wrapping is not required; truncation is acceptable if the component's 5730wrapping is not required; truncation is acceptable if the component's
5731full content is available on focus or after user activation and an 5731full content is available on focus or after user activation and an
5732indication that this information can be accessed, is provided to the 5732indication that this information can be accessed, is provided to the
5733user in some way besides the fact that it is truncated. 5733user in some way besides the fact that it is truncated.
5734  5734 
5735Content satisfies the Success Criterion if it can be scaled up to 200%, 5735Content satisfies the Success Criterion if it can be scaled up to 200%,
5736that is, up to twice the width and height. Authors may support scaling 5736that is, up to twice the width and height. Authors may support scaling
5737beyond that limit, however, as scaling becomes more extreme, adaptive 5737beyond that limit, however, as scaling becomes more extreme, adaptive
5738layouts may introduce usability problems. For example, words may be too 5738layouts may introduce usability problems. For example, words may be too
5739wide to fit into the horizontal space available to them, causing them to 5739wide to fit into the horizontal space available to them, causing them to
5740be truncated; layout constraints may cause text to overlap with other 5740be truncated; layout constraints may cause text to overlap with other
5741content when it is scaled larger; or only one word of a sentence may fit 5741content when it is scaled larger; or only one word of a sentence may fit
5742on each line, causing the sentence to be displayed as a vertical column 5742on each line, causing the sentence to be displayed as a vertical column
5743of text that is difficult to read. 5743of text that is difficult to read.
5744  5744 
5745The working group feels that 200% is a reasonable accommodation that can 5745The working group feels that 200% is a reasonable accommodation that can
5746support a wide range of designs and layouts, and complements older 5746support a wide range of designs and layouts, and complements older
5747screen magnifiers that provide a minimum magnification of 200%. Above 5747screen magnifiers that provide a minimum magnification of 200%. Above
5748200%, zoom (which resizes text, images, and layout regions and creates a 5748200%, zoom (which resizes text, images, and layout regions and creates a
5749larger canvas that may require both horizontal and vertical scrolling) 5749larger canvas that may require both horizontal and vertical scrolling)
5750may be more effective than text resizing. Assistive technology dedicated 5750may be more effective than text resizing. Assistive technology dedicated
5751to zoom support would usually be used in such a situation and may 5751to zoom support would usually be used in such a situation and may
5752provide better accessibility than attempts by the author to support the 5752provide better accessibility than attempts by the author to support the
5753user directly. 5753user directly.
5754  5754 
5755/Note: /Images of text do not scale as well as text because they tend to 5755/Note: /Images of text do not scale as well as text because they tend to
5756pixelate, and therefore we suggest using text wherever possible. It is 5756pixelate, and therefore we suggest using text wherever possible. It is
5757also harder to change foreground and background contrast and color 5757also harder to change foreground and background contrast and color
5758combinations for images of text, which are necessary for some users. 5758combinations for images of text, which are necessary for some users.
5759  5759 
5760See also /Understanding Success Criterion 1.4.8 Visual Presentation 5760See also /Understanding Success Criterion 1.4.8 Visual Presentation
5761<#visual-audio-contrast-visual-presentation>/. 5761<#visual-audio-contrast-visual-presentation>/.

5765  5765 
5766  * 5766  *
5767  5767 
5768    This Success Criterion helps people with low vision by letting them 5768    This Success Criterion helps people with low vision by letting them
5769    increase text size in content so that they can read it. 5769    increase text size in content so that they can read it.
5770  5770 
5771  5771 
5772      Examples of Success Criterion 1.4.4 5772      Examples of Success Criterion 1.4.4
5773  5773 
5774  * 5774  *
5775  5775 
5776    A user with vision impairments increases the text size on a Web page 5776    A user with vision impairments increases the text size on a Web page
5777    in a browser from 1 em to 1.2 ems. While the user could not read the 5777    in a browser from 1 em to 1.2 ems. While the user could not read the
5778    text at the smaller size, she can read the larger text. All the 5778    text at the smaller size, she can read the larger text. All the
5779    information on the page is still displayed when the larger font is 5779    information on the page is still displayed when the larger font is
5780    used for the text. 5780    used for the text.
5781  5781 
5782  * 5782  *
5783  5783 
5784    A Web page contains a control for changing the scale of the page. 5784    A Web page contains a control for changing the scale of the page.
5785    Selecting different settings changes the layout of the page to use 5785    Selecting different settings changes the layout of the page to use
5786    the best design for that scale. 5786    the best design for that scale.
5787  5787 
5788  * 5788  *
5789  5789 
5790    A user uses a zoom function in his user agent to change the scale of 5790    A user uses a zoom function in his user agent to change the scale of
5791    the content. All the content scales uniformly, and the user agent 5791    the content. All the content scales uniformly, and the user agent
5792    provides scroll bars, if necessary. 5792    provides scroll bars, if necessary.

6013    hardware and/or software that acts as a user agent 6013    hardware and/or software that acts as a user agent
6014    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#useragentdef>, or 6014    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#useragentdef>, or
6015    along with a mainstream user agent, to provide functionality to meet 6015    along with a mainstream user agent, to provide functionality to meet

6018  6018 
6019    /Note 1: / functionality provided by assistive technology includes 6019    /Note 1: / functionality provided by assistive technology includes
6020    alternative presentations (e.g., as synthesized speech or magnified 6020    alternative presentations (e.g., as synthesized speech or magnified
6021    content), alternative input methods (e.g., voice), additional 6021    content), alternative input methods (e.g., voice), additional
6022    navigation or orientation mechanisms, and content transformations 6022    navigation or orientation mechanisms, and content transformations
6023    (e.g., to make tables more accessible). 6023    (e.g., to make tables more accessible).
6024  6024 
6025    /Note 2: /Assistive technologies often communicate data and messages 6025    /Note 2: /Assistive technologies often communicate data and messages
6026    with mainstream user agents by using and monitoring APIs. 6026    with mainstream user agents by using and monitoring APIs.
6027  6027 
6028    /Note 3: /The distinction between mainstream user agents and 6028    /Note 3: /The distinction between mainstream user agents and
6029    assistive technologies is not absolute. Many mainstream user agents 6029    assistive technologies is not absolute. Many mainstream user agents
6030    provide some features to assist individuals with disabilities. The 6030    provide some features to assist individuals with disabilities. The
6031    basic difference is that mainstream user agents target broad and 6031    basic difference is that mainstream user agents target broad and
6032    diverse audiences that usually include people with and without 6032    diverse audiences that usually include people with and without
6033    disabilities. Assistive technologies target narrowly defined 6033    disabilities. Assistive technologies target narrowly defined
6034    populations of users with specific disabilities. The assistance 6034    populations of users with specific disabilities. The assistance
6035    provided by an assistive technology is more specific and appropriate 6035    provided by an assistive technology is more specific and appropriate
6036    to the needs of its target users. The mainstream user agent may 6036    to the needs of its target users. The mainstream user agent may
6037    provide important functionality to assistive technologies like 6037    provide important functionality to assistive technologies like
6038    retrieving Web content from program objects or parsing markup into 6038    retrieving Web content from program objects or parsing markup into
6039    identifiable bundles. 6039    identifiable bundles.
6040  6040 
6041    /Example: /Assistive technologies that are important in the context 6041    /Example: /Assistive technologies that are important in the context
6042    of this document include the following: 6042    of this document include the following:

6157  6157 
6158    /Note: /Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are 6158    /Note: /Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are
6159    considered essential. 6159    considered essential.
6160  6160 
6161  6161 
6162      Intent of this Success Criterion 6162      Intent of this Success Criterion
6163  6163 
6164The intent of this Success Criterion is to encourage authors, who are 6164The intent of this Success Criterion is to encourage authors, who are
6165using technologies which are capable of achieving their desired default 6165using technologies which are capable of achieving their desired default
6166visual presentation, to enable people who require a particular visual 6166visual presentation, to enable people who require a particular visual
6167presentation of text to be able to adjust the text presentation as 6167presentation of text to be able to adjust the text presentation as
6168needed. This includes people who require the text in a particular font 6168needed. This includes people who require the text in a particular font
6169size, foreground and background color, font family, line spacing or 6169size, foreground and background color, font family, line spacing or
6170alignment. 6170alignment.
6171  6171 
6172If an author can use text to achieve the same visual effect, he or she 6172If an author can use text to achieve the same visual effect, he or she
6173should present the information as text rather than using an image. If 6173should present the information as text rather than using an image. If
6174for any reason, the author cannot format the text to get the same 6174for any reason, the author cannot format the text to get the same
6175effect, the effect won't be reliably presented on the commonly available 6175effect, the effect won't be reliably presented on the commonly available
6176user agents, or using a technology to meet this criterion would 6176user agents, or using a technology to meet this criterion would
6177interfere with meeting other criterion such as 1.4.4, then an image of 6177interfere with meeting other criterion such as 1.4.4, then an image of
6178text can be used. This includes instances where a particular 6178text can be used. This includes instances where a particular
6179presentation of text is essential to the information being conveyed, 6179presentation of text is essential to the information being conveyed,
6180such as type samples, logotypes, branding, etc. Images of text may also 6180such as type samples, logotypes, branding, etc. Images of text may also
6181be used in order to use a particular font that is either not widely 6181be used in order to use a particular font that is either not widely
6182deployed or which the author doesn't have the right to redistribute, or 6182deployed or which the author doesn't have the right to redistribute, or
6183to ensure that the text would be anti-aliased on all user agents. 6183to ensure that the text would be anti-aliased on all user agents.
6184  6184 
6185Images of text can also be used where it is possible for users to 6185Images of text can also be used where it is possible for users to
6186customize the image of text to match their requirements. 6186customize the image of text to match their requirements.
6187  6187 
6188The definition of image of text contains the note: "Note: This does not 6188The definition of image of text contains the note: "Note: This does not
6189include text that is part of a picture that contains significant other 6189include text that is part of a picture that contains significant other
6190visual content." Examples of such pictures include graphs, screenshots, 6190visual content." Examples of such pictures include graphs, screenshots,
6191and diagrams which visually convey important information through more 6191and diagrams which visually convey important information through more
6192than just text. 6192than just text.
6193  6193 
6194Techniques for satisfying this Success Criterion are the same as those 6194Techniques for satisfying this Success Criterion are the same as those
6195for Success Criterion 1.4.9, except that they only need to apply if the 6195for Success Criterion 1.4.9, except that they only need to apply if the
6196visual presentation can be achieved with the technologies that the 6196visual presentation can be achieved with the technologies that the
6197author is using. For Success Criterion 1.4.9, the sufficient techniques 6197author is using. For Success Criterion 1.4.9, the sufficient techniques
6198would be applied only when the user can customize the output. 6198would be applied only when the user can customize the output.

6228    font and size, an author uses CSS to achieve the same result. 6228    font and size, an author uses CSS to achieve the same result.

6232    *Dynamically Generated Images * 6232    *Dynamically Generated Images *
6233  6233 
6234    A Web page uses server-side scripting to present text as an an 6234    A Web page uses server-side scripting to present text as an an
6235    image. The page includes controls that allow the user to adjust the 6235    image. The page includes controls that allow the user to adjust the
6236    font size and foreground and background colors of the generated image. 6236    font size and foreground and background colors of the generated image.
6237  6237 
6238  * 6238  *
6239  6239 
6240    *A quote* 6240    *A quote*
6241  6241 
6242    A Web page contains a quote. The quote itself is presented as 6242    A Web page contains a quote. The quote itself is presented as
6243    italicized text, indented from the left margin. The name of the 6243    italicized text, indented from the left margin. The name of the
6244    person to whom the quote is attributed is below the quote with 1.5x 6244    person to whom the quote is attributed is below the quote with 1.5x
6245    the line space and further indented from the left margin. CSS is 6245    the line space and further indented from the left margin. CSS is
6246    used to position the text; set the spacing between lines; as well as 6246    used to position the text; set the spacing between lines; as well as
6247    display the text's font family, size, color and decoration. 6247    display the text's font family, size, color and decoration.
6248  6248

6254    icon and text to describe their target. CSS is used to display the 6254    icon and text to describe their target. CSS is used to display the
6255    text's font family, size and foreground and background colors; as 6255    text's font family, size and foreground and background colors; as
6256    well as the spacing between the navigation links. 6256    well as the spacing between the navigation links.

6263    of each Web page. The logo contains logotype (text as part, or all, 6263    of each Web page. The logo contains logotype (text as part, or all,

6265    the identity of the logo and is included as a gif image which does 6265    the identity of the logo and is included as a gif image which does
6266    not allow the text characteristics to be changed. The image has a 6266    not allow the text characteristics to be changed. The image has a

6275    purpose of the representation. The representation is included as a 6275    purpose of the representation. The representation is included as a

6295    number of buttons, including functions to style the text and check 6295    number of buttons, including functions to style the text and check
6296    spelling. Some of the buttons use text characters that do not form a 6296    spelling. Some of the buttons use text characters that do not form a
6297    sequence that expresses something in human language. For example "B" 6297    sequence that expresses something in human language. For example "B"
6298    to increase font weight, "I" to italicize the text and "ABC" to 6298    to increase font weight, "I" to italicize the text and "ABC" to
6299    check the spelling. The symbolic text characters are included as gif 6299    check the spelling. The symbolic text characters are included as gif
6300    images which do not allow the text characteristics to be changed. 6300    images which do not allow the text characteristics to be changed.
6301    The buttons have text alternatives. 6301    The buttons have text alternatives.

6497        *Logotypes: * Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no 6497        *Logotypes: * Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no

6500  6500 
6501      Intent of this Success Criterion 6501      Intent of this Success Criterion
6502  6502 
6503The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide enough contrast 6503The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide enough contrast
6504between text and its background so that it can be read by people with 6504between text and its background so that it can be read by people with
6505moderately low vision (who do not use contrast-enhancing assistive 6505moderately low vision (who do not use contrast-enhancing assistive
6506technology). For people without color deficiencies, hue and saturation 6506technology). For people without color deficiencies, hue and saturation
6507have minimal or no effect on legibility as assessed by reading 6507have minimal or no effect on legibility as assessed by reading
6508performance (Knoblauch et al., 1991). Color deficiencies can affect 6508performance (Knoblauch et al., 1991). Color deficiencies can affect
6509luminance contrast somewhat. Therefore, in the recommendation, the 6509luminance contrast somewhat. Therefore, in the recommendation, the
6510contrast is calculated in such a way that color is not a key factor so 6510contrast is calculated in such a way that color is not a key factor so
6511that people who have a color vision deficit will also have adequate 6511that people who have a color vision deficit will also have adequate
6512contrast between the text and the background. 6512contrast between the text and the background.
6513  6513 
6514Text that is decorative and conveys no information is excluded. For 6514Text that is decorative and conveys no information is excluded. For
6515example, if random words are used to create a background and the words 6515example, if random words are used to create a background and the words
6516could be rearranged or substituted without changing meaning, then it 6516could be rearranged or substituted without changing meaning, then it
6517would be decorative and would not need to meet this criterion. 6517would be decorative and would not need to meet this criterion.
6518  6518 
6519Text that is larger and has wider character strokes is easier to read at 6519Text that is larger and has wider character strokes is easier to read at
6520lower contrast. The contrast requirement for larger text is therefore 6520lower contrast. The contrast requirement for larger text is therefore
6521lower. This allows authors to use a wider range of color choices for 6521lower. This allows authors to use a wider range of color choices for
6522large text, which is helpful for design of pages, particularly titles. 6522large text, which is helpful for design of pages, particularly titles.
652318 point text or 14 point bold text is judged to be large enough to 652318 point text or 14 point bold text is judged to be large enough to
6524require a lower contrast ratio. (See The American Printing House for the 6524require a lower contrast ratio. (See The American Printing House for the
6525Blind Guidelines for Large Printing and The Library of Congress 6525Blind Guidelines for Large Printing and The Library of Congress
6526Guidelines for Large Print under Resources 6526Guidelines for Large Print under Resources
6527<#visual-audio-contrast7-resources-head>). "18 point" and "bold" can 6527<#visual-audio-contrast7-resources-head>). "18 point" and "bold" can
6528both have different meanings in different fonts but, except for very 6528both have different meanings in different fonts but, except for very
6529thin or unusual fonts, they should be sufficient. Since there are so 6529thin or unusual fonts, they should be sufficient. Since there are so
6530many different fonts, the general measures are used and a note regarding 6530many different fonts, the general measures are used and a note regarding
6531fancy or thin fonts is included. 6531fancy or thin fonts is included.
6532  6532 
6533/Note 1: /When fonts have anti-aliasing applied to make them look 6533/Note 1: /When fonts have anti-aliasing applied to make them look
6534smoother, they can lose darkness or lightness. Thus, the actual contrast 6534smoother, they can lose darkness or lightness. Thus, the actual contrast
6535can be reduced. Thicker stem widths will reduce this effect (thin fonts 6535can be reduced. Thicker stem widths will reduce this effect (thin fonts
6536could have the full stem lightened rather than just the ends). Using 6536could have the full stem lightened rather than just the ends). Using
6537larger fonts and testing for legibility in user agents with font 6537larger fonts and testing for legibility in user agents with font
6538smoothing turned on is recommended. 6538smoothing turned on is recommended.
6539  6539 
6540/Note 2: /Because different image editing applications default to 6540/Note 2: /Because different image editing applications default to
6541different pixel densities (ex. 72 PPI or 96 PPI), specifying point sizes 6541different pixel densities (ex. 72 PPI or 96 PPI), specifying point sizes
6542for fonts from within an image editing application can be unreliable 6542for fonts from within an image editing application can be unreliable
6543when it comes to presenting text at a specific size. When creating 6543when it comes to presenting text at a specific size. When creating
6544images of large-scale text, authors should ensure that the text in the 6544images of large-scale text, authors should ensure that the text in the
6545resulting image is roughly equivalent to 1.2 and 1.5 em or to 120% or 6545resulting image is roughly equivalent to 1.2 and 1.5 em or to 120% or
6546150% of the default size for body text. For example, for a 72 PPI image, 6546150% of the default size for body text. For example, for a 72 PPI image,
6547an author would need to use approximately 19 pt and 24 pt font sizes in 6547an author would need to use approximately 19 pt and 24 pt font sizes in
6548order to successfully present large-scale images of text to a user. 6548order to successfully present large-scale images of text to a user.

6551images of text (text that has been rendered into pixels and then stored 6551images of text (text that has been rendered into pixels and then stored
6552in an image format) as stated in Success Criterion 1.4.5 6552in an image format) as stated in Success Criterion 1.4.5
6553  6553 
6554This requirement applies to situations in which images of text were 6554This requirement applies to situations in which images of text were
6555intended to be understood as text. Incidental text, such as in 6555intended to be understood as text. Incidental text, such as in
6556photographs that happen to include a street sign, are not included. Nor 6556photographs that happen to include a street sign, are not included. Nor
6557is text that for some reason is designed to be invisible to all users. 6557is text that for some reason is designed to be invisible to all users.
6558Stylized text, such as in corporate logos, should be treated in terms of 6558Stylized text, such as in corporate logos, should be treated in terms of
6559its function on the page, which may or may not warrant including the 6559its function on the page, which may or may not warrant including the
6560content in the text alternative. Corporate visual guidelines beyond logo 6560content in the text alternative. Corporate visual guidelines beyond logo
6561and logotype are not included in the exception. 6561and logotype are not included in the exception.

6564picture that contains significant other visual content,". This exception 6564picture that contains significant other visual content,". This exception
6565is intended to separate pictures that have text in them from images of 6565is intended to separate pictures that have text in them from images of
6566text that are done to replace text in order to get a particular look. 6566text that are done to replace text in order to get a particular look.

6569occur for data presented in charts or graphs. Good color contrast should 6569occur for data presented in charts or graphs. Good color contrast should
6570also be provided for data presented in these forms. 6570also be provided for data presented in these forms.
