6572  6572 
6573        Rationale for the Ratios Chosen 6573        Rationale for the Ratios Chosen
6574  6574 
6575A contrast ratio of 3:1 is the minimum level recommended by [ISO-9241-3] 6575A contrast ratio of 3:1 is the minimum level recommended by [ISO-9241-3]
6576<#ISO-9241-3> and [ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> for 6576<#ISO-9241-3> and [ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> for
6577standard text and vision. The 4.5:1 ratio is used in Success Criterion 6577standard text and vision. The 4.5:1 ratio is used in Success Criterion
65781.4.3 to account for the loss in contrast that results from moderately 65781.4.3 to account for the loss in contrast that results from moderately
6579low visual acuity, congenital or acquired color deficiencies, or the 6579low visual acuity, congenital or acquired color deficiencies, or the
6580loss of contrast sensitivity that typically accompanies aging. 6580loss of contrast sensitivity that typically accompanies aging.
6581  6581 
6582The rationale is based on a) adoption of the 3:1 contrast ratio for 6582The rationale is based on a) adoption of the 3:1 contrast ratio for
6583minimum acceptable contrast for normal observers, in the ANSI standard, 6583minimum acceptable contrast for normal observers, in the ANSI standard,
6584and b) the empirical finding that in the population, visual acuity of 6584and b) the empirical finding that in the population, visual acuity of
658520/40 is associated with a contrast sensitivity loss of roughly 1.5 658520/40 is associated with a contrast sensitivity loss of roughly 1.5
6586[ARDITI-FAYE] <#ARDITI-FAYE>. A user with 20/40 would thus require a 6586[ARDITI-FAYE] <#ARDITI-FAYE>. A user with 20/40 would thus require a
6587contrast ratio of 3 * 1.5 = 4.5 to 1. Following analogous empirical 6587contrast ratio of 3 * 1.5 = 4.5 to 1. Following analogous empirical
6588findings and the same logic, the user with 20/80 visual acuity would 6588findings and the same logic, the user with 20/80 visual acuity would
6589require contrast of about 7:1. 6589require contrast of about 7:1.
6590  6590 
6591Hues are perceived differently by users with color vision deficiencies 6591Hues are perceived differently by users with color vision deficiencies
6592(both congenital and acquired) resulting in different colors and 6592(both congenital and acquired) resulting in different colors and
6593relative luminance contrasts than for normally sighted users. Because of 6593relative luminance contrasts than for normally sighted users. Because of
6594this, effective contrast and readability are different for this 6594this, effective contrast and readability are different for this
6595population. However, color deficiencies are so diverse that prescribing 6595population. However, color deficiencies are so diverse that prescribing
6596effective general use color pairs (for contrast) based on quantitative 6596effective general use color pairs (for contrast) based on quantitative
6597data is not feasible. Requiring good luminance contrast accommodates 6597data is not feasible. Requiring good luminance contrast accommodates
6598this by requiring contrast that is independent of color perception. 6598this by requiring contrast that is independent of color perception.
6599Fortunately, most of the luminance contribution is from the mid and long 6599Fortunately, most of the luminance contribution is from the mid and long
6600wave receptors which largely overlap in their spectral responses. The 6600wave receptors which largely overlap in their spectral responses. The
6601result is that effective luminance contrast can generally be computed 6601result is that effective luminance contrast can generally be computed
6602without regard to specific color deficiency, except for the use of 6602without regard to specific color deficiency, except for the use of
6603predominantly long wavelength colors against darker colors (generally 6603predominantly long wavelength colors against darker colors (generally
6604appearing black) for those who have protanopia. (We provide an advisory 6604appearing black) for those who have protanopia. (We provide an advisory
6605technique on avoiding red on black for that reason). For more 6605technique on avoiding red on black for that reason). For more
6606information see [ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH] <#ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1994> 6606information see [ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH] <#ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1994>
6607[ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1996] <#ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1996> [ARDITI] <#ARDITI>. 6607[ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1996] <#ARDITI-KNOBLAUCH-1996> [ARDITI] <#ARDITI>.
6608  6608 
6609The contrast ratio of 4.5:1 was chosen for level AA because it 6609The contrast ratio of 4.5:1 was chosen for level AA because it
6610compensated for the loss in contrast sensitivity usually experienced by 6610compensated for the loss in contrast sensitivity usually experienced by
6611users with vision loss equivalent to approximately 20/40 vision. (20/40 6611users with vision loss equivalent to approximately 20/40 vision. (20/40
6612calculates to approximately 4.5:1.) 20/40 is commonly reported as 6612calculates to approximately 4.5:1.) 20/40 is commonly reported as
6613typical visual acuity of elders at roughly age 80. [GITTINGS-FOZARD] 6613typical visual acuity of elders at roughly age 80. [GITTINGS-FOZARD]
6614<#GITTINGS-FOZARD> 6614<#GITTINGS-FOZARD>
6615  6615 
6616The contrast ratio of 7:1 was chosen for level AAA because it 6616The contrast ratio of 7:1 was chosen for level AAA because it
6617compensated for the loss in contrast sensitivity usually experienced by 6617compensated for the loss in contrast sensitivity usually experienced by
6618users with vision loss equivalent to approximately 20/80 vision. People 6618users with vision loss equivalent to approximately 20/80 vision. People
6619with more than this degree of vision loss usually use assistive 6619with more than this degree of vision loss usually use assistive
6620technologies to access their content (and the assistive technologies 6620technologies to access their content (and the assistive technologies
6621usually have contrast enhancing, as well as magnification capability 6621usually have contrast enhancing, as well as magnification capability
6622built into them). The 7:1 level therefore generally provides 6622built into them). The 7:1 level therefore generally provides
6623compensation for the loss in contrast sensitivity experienced by users 6623compensation for the loss in contrast sensitivity experienced by users
6624with low vision who do not use assistive technology and provides 6624with low vision who do not use assistive technology and provides
6625contrast enhancement for color deficiency as well. 6625contrast enhancement for color deficiency as well.
6626  6626 
6627/Note: /Calculations in [ISO-9241-3] <#ISO-9241-3> and 6627/Note: /Calculations in [ISO-9241-3] <#ISO-9241-3> and
6628[ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> are for body text. A relaxed 6628[ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> are for body text. A relaxed
6629contrast ratio is provided for text that is much larger. 6629contrast ratio is provided for text that is much larger.

6633  6633 
6634Conversion from nonlinear to linear RGB values is based on IEC/4WD 6634Conversion from nonlinear to linear RGB values is based on IEC/4WD
663561966-2-1 [IEC-4WD] <#IEC-4WD> and on "A Standard Default Color Space 663561966-2-1 [IEC-4WD] <#IEC-4WD> and on "A Standard Default Color Space
6636for the Internet - sRGB" [sRGB] <#sRGB>. 6636for the Internet - sRGB" [sRGB] <#sRGB>.
6637  6637 
6638The formula (L1/L2) for contrast is based on [ISO-9241-3] <#ISO-9241-3> 6638The formula (L1/L2) for contrast is based on [ISO-9241-3] <#ISO-9241-3>
6639and [ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> standards. 6639and [ANSI-HFES-100-1988] <#ANSI-HFES-100-1988> standards.
6640  6640 
6641The ANSI/HFS 100-1988 standard calls for the contribution from ambient 6641The ANSI/HFS 100-1988 standard calls for the contribution from ambient
6642light to be included in the calculation of L1 and L2. The .05 value used 6642light to be included in the calculation of L1 and L2. The .05 value used
6643is based on Typical Viewing Flare from [IEC-4WD] <#IEC-4WD> and the 6643is based on Typical Viewing Flare from [IEC-4WD] <#IEC-4WD> and the
6644[sRGB] <#sRGB> paper by M. Stokes et al. 6644[sRGB] <#sRGB> paper by M. Stokes et al.
6645  6645 
6646This Success Criterion and its definitions use the terms "contrast 6646This Success Criterion and its definitions use the terms "contrast
6647ratio" and "relative luminance" rather than "luminance" to reflect the 6647ratio" and "relative luminance" rather than "luminance" to reflect the
6648fact that Web content does not emit light itself. The contrast ratio 6648fact that Web content does not emit light itself. The contrast ratio
6649gives a measure of the relative luminance that would result when 6649gives a measure of the relative luminance that would result when
6650displayed. (Because it is a ratio, it is dimensionless.) 6650displayed. (Because it is a ratio, it is dimensionless.)

6654utilize the contrast ratio to analyze the contrast of Web content. 6654utilize the contrast ratio to analyze the contrast of Web content.

6661        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 1.4.6 6661        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 1.4.6
6662  6662 
6663  * 6663  *
6664  6664 
6665    People with low vision often have difficulty reading text that does 6665    People with low vision often have difficulty reading text that does
6666    not contrast with its background. This can be exacerbated if the 6666    not contrast with its background. This can be exacerbated if the
6667    person has a color vision deficiency that lowers the contrast even 6667    person has a color vision deficiency that lowers the contrast even
6668    further. Providing a minimum luminance contrast ratio between the 6668    further. Providing a minimum luminance contrast ratio between the
6669    text and its background can make the text more readable even if the 6669    text and its background can make the text more readable even if the
6670    person does not see the full range of colors. It also works for the 6670    person does not see the full range of colors. It also works for the
6671    rare individuals who see no color. 6671    rare individuals who see no color.

6982    does not include resizing that may be done by a user. 6982    does not include resizing that may be done by a user.

6984    /Note 3: /The actual size of the character that a user sees is 6984    /Note 3: /The actual size of the character that a user sees is
6985    dependent both on the author-defined size and the user's display or 6985    dependent both on the author-defined size and the user's display or
6986    user-agent settings. For many mainstream body text fonts, 14 and 18 6986    user-agent settings. For many mainstream body text fonts, 14 and 18
6987    point is roughly equivalent to 1.2 and 1.5 em or to 120% or 150% of 6987    point is roughly equivalent to 1.2 and 1.5 em or to 120% or 150% of
6988    the default size for body text (assuming that the body font is 6988    the default size for body text (assuming that the body font is
6989    100%), but authors would need to check this for the particular fonts 6989    100%), but authors would need to check this for the particular fonts
6990    in use. When fonts are defined in relative units, the actual point 6990    in use. When fonts are defined in relative units, the actual point
6991    size is calculated by the user agent for display. The point size 6991    size is calculated by the user agent for display. The point size
6992    should be obtained from the user agent, or calculated based on font 6992    should be obtained from the user agent, or calculated based on font
6993    metrics as the user agent does, when evaluating this success 6993    metrics as the user agent does, when evaluating this success
6994    criterion. Users who have low vision would be responsible for 6994    criterion. Users who have low vision would be responsible for
6995    choosing appropriate settings. 6995    choosing appropriate settings.
6996  6996 
6997    /Note 4: /When using text without specifying the font size, the 6997    /Note 4: /When using text without specifying the font size, the
6998    smallest font size used on major browsers for unspecified text would 6998    smallest font size used on major browsers for unspecified text would
6999    be a reasonable size to assume for the font. If a level 1 heading is 6999    be a reasonable size to assume for the font. If a level 1 heading is
7000    rendered in 14pt bold or higher on major browsers, then it would be 7000    rendered in 14pt bold or higher on major browsers, then it would be
7001    reasonable to assume it is large text. Relative scaling can be 7001    reasonable to assume it is large text. Relative scaling can be
7002    calculated from the default sizes in a similar fashion. 7002    calculated from the default sizes in a similar fashion.
7003  7003 
7004    /Note 5: /The 18 and 14 point sizes for roman texts are taken from 7004    /Note 5: /The 18 and 14 point sizes for roman texts are taken from
7005    the minimum size for large print (14pt) and the larger standard font 7005    the minimum size for large print (14pt) and the larger standard font
7006    size (18pt). For other fonts such as CJK languages, the "equivalent" 7006    size (18pt). For other fonts such as CJK languages, the "equivalent"
7007    sizes would be the minimum large print size used for those languages 7007    sizes would be the minimum large print size used for those languages
7008    and the next larger standard large print size. 7008    and the next larger standard large print size.

7011  7011 
7012    serving only an aesthetic purpose, providing no information, and 7012    serving only an aesthetic purpose, providing no information, and
7013    having no functionality 7013    having no functionality

7022  7022 
7023    sequence of characters that can be programmatically determined 7023    sequence of characters that can be programmatically determined

7076        than the foreground speech content, with the exception of 7076        than the foreground speech content, with the exception of
7077        occasional sounds that last for only one or two seconds. 7077        occasional sounds that last for only one or two seconds.

7080        meets this requirement will be approximately four times quieter 7080        meets this requirement will be approximately four times quieter
7081        than the foreground speech content. 7081        than the foreground speech content.

7084      Intent of this Success Criterion 7084      Intent of this Success Criterion
7085  7085 
7086The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that any non-speech 7086The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that any non-speech
7087sounds are low enough that a user who is hard of hearing can separate 7087sounds are low enough that a user who is hard of hearing can separate
7088the speech from background sounds or other noise foreground speech content. 7088the speech from background sounds or other noise foreground speech content.
7089  7089 
7090The value of 20 dB was chosen based on Large area assistive listening 7090The value of 20 dB was chosen based on Large area assistive listening
7091systems (ALS): Review and recommendations [LAALS] <#LAALS> and 7091systems (ALS): Review and recommendations [LAALS] <#LAALS> and
7092In-the-ear measurements of interference in hearing aids from digital 7092In-the-ear measurements of interference in hearing aids from digital
7093wireless telephones [HEARING-AID-INT] <#HEARING-AID-INT> 7093wireless telephones [HEARING-AID-INT] <#HEARING-AID-INT>

7176    differentiate a human from a computer. It is named after famed 7176    differentiate a human from a computer. It is named after famed

7233      Intent of this Success Criterion 7233      Intent of this Success Criterion
7234  7234 
7235The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that visually rendered 7235The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that visually rendered
7236text is presented in such a manner that it can be perceived without its 7236text is presented in such a manner that it can be perceived without its
7237layout interfering with its readability. People with some cognitive, 7237layout interfering with its readability. People with some cognitive,
7238language and learning disabilities and some low vision users cannot 7238language and learning disabilities and some low vision users cannot
7239perceive the text and/or lose their reading place if the text is 7239perceive the text and/or lose their reading place if the text is
7240presented in a manner that is difficult for them to read. 7240presented in a manner that is difficult for them to read.
7241  7241 
7242People with some visual or cognitive disabilities need to be able to 7242People with some visual or cognitive disabilities need to be able to
7243select the color of text and the color of the background. They sometimes 7243select the color of text and the color of the background. They sometimes
7244choose combinations that seem unintuitive to someone without that 7244choose combinations that seem unintuitive to someone without that
7245disability. Sometimes these combinations have very low contrast. 7245disability. Sometimes these combinations have very low contrast.
7246Sometimes only very specific color combinations work for them. Control 7246Sometimes only very specific color combinations work for them. Control
7247of color or other aspects of text presentation makes a huge difference 7247of color or other aspects of text presentation makes a huge difference
7248to their comprehension. 7248to their comprehension.
7249  7249 
7250For people with some reading or vision disabilities, long lines of text 7250For people with some reading or vision disabilities, long lines of text
7251can become a significant barrier. They have trouble keeping their place 7251can become a significant barrier. They have trouble keeping their place
7252and following the flow of text. Having a narrow block of text makes it 7252and following the flow of text. Having a narrow block of text makes it
7253easier for them to continue on to the next line in a block. Lines should 7253easier for them to continue on to the next line in a block. Lines should
7254not exceed 80 characters or glyphs (40 if CJK), where glyphs are the 7254not exceed 80 characters or glyphs (40 if CJK), where glyphs are the
7255element of writing in the writing system for the text.. Studies have 7255element of writing in the writing system for the text.. Studies have
7256shown that Chinese, Japanese and Korean (CJK) characters are 7256shown that Chinese, Japanese and Korean (CJK) characters are
7257approximately twice as wide as non-CJK characters when both types of 7257approximately twice as wide as non-CJK characters when both types of
7258characters are displayed with characteristics that achieve the same 7258characters are displayed with characteristics that achieve the same
7259readability, so the maximum line width for CJK characters is half that 7259readability, so the maximum line width for CJK characters is half that
7260of non-CJK characters. 7260of non-CJK characters.
7261  7261 
7262People with some cognitive disabilities find it difficult to track text 7262People with some cognitive disabilities find it difficult to track text
7263where the lines are close together. Providing extra space between lines 7263where the lines are close together. Providing extra space between lines
7264and paragraphs allows them to better track the next line and to 7264and paragraphs allows them to better track the next line and to
7265recognize when they have reached the end of a paragraph. It is best if 7265recognize when they have reached the end of a paragraph. It is best if
7266there are several different options, for instance, space-and-a-half and 7266there are several different options, for instance, space-and-a-half and
7267double spacing for line spacing. By space and a half within paragraphs 7267double spacing for line spacing. By space and a half within paragraphs
7268we mean that top of one line is 150% further from the top of the line 7268we mean that top of one line is 150% further from the top of the line
7269below it than would be true when the text is 'single spaced' (the 7269below it than would be true when the text is 'single spaced' (the
7270default spacing for the font). By Paragraph spacing that is 1.5 times 7270default spacing for the font). By Paragraph spacing that is 1.5 times
7271larger than the line spacing we mean that the spacing from the top of 7271larger than the line spacing we mean that the spacing from the top of
7272the last line of 1 paragraph is 250% farther from the Top of the first 7272the last line of 1 paragraph is 250% farther from the Top of the first
7273line of the next paragraph (i.e., that there is a blank line between the 7273line of the next paragraph (i.e., that there is a blank line between the
7274two paragraphs that is 150% of the single space blank line). 7274two paragraphs that is 150% of the single space blank line).
7275  7275 
7276People with certain cognitive disabilities have problems reading text 7276People with certain cognitive disabilities have problems reading text
7277that is both left and right justified. The uneven spacing between words 7277that is both left and right justified. The uneven spacing between words
7278in fully justified text can cause "rivers of white" space to run down 7278in fully justified text can cause "rivers of white" space to run down
7279the page making reading difficult and in some cases impossible. Text 7279the page making reading difficult and in some cases impossible. Text
7280justification can also cause words to be spaced closely together, so 7280justification can also cause words to be spaced closely together, so
7281that it is difficult for them to locate word boundaries. 7281that it is difficult for them to locate word boundaries.
7282  7282 
7283The resizing provision ensures that visually rendered text (text 7283The resizing provision ensures that visually rendered text (text
7284characters that have been displayed so that they can be seen [vs. text 7284characters that have been displayed so that they can be seen [vs. text
7285characters that are still in data form such as ASCII]) can be scaled 7285characters that are still in data form such as ASCII]) can be scaled
7286successfully without requiring that the user scroll left and right to 7286successfully without requiring that the user scroll left and right to
7287see all of the content. When the content has been authored so that this 7287see all of the content. When the content has been authored so that this
7288is possible, the content is said to reflow. This permits people with low 7288is possible, the content is said to reflow. This permits people with low
7289vision and people with cognitive disabilities to increase the size of 7289vision and people with cognitive disabilities to increase the size of
7290the text without becoming disoriented. 7290the text without becoming disoriented.
7291  7291 
7292The scaling of content is primarily a user agent responsibility. User 7292The scaling of content is primarily a user agent responsibility. User
7293agents that satisfy UAAG 1.0 Checkpoint 4.1 allow users to configure 7293agents that satisfy UAAG 1.0 Checkpoint 4.1 allow users to configure
7294text scale. The author's responsibility is to create Web content that 7294text scale. The author's responsibility is to create Web content that
7295does not prevent the user agent from scaling the content and that allows 7295does not prevent the user agent from scaling the content and that allows
7296the reflow of the content within the current width of the viewport. See 7296the reflow of the content within the current width of the viewport. See
7297/Understanding Success Criterion 1.4.4 Resize text 7297/Understanding Success Criterion 1.4.4 Resize text
7298<#visual-audio-contrast-scale>/ for additional discussion of resizing text. 7298<#visual-audio-contrast-scale>/ for additional discussion of resizing text.
7299  7299 
7300The horizontal scrolling requirement is not intended to apply to 7300The horizontal scrolling requirement is not intended to apply to
7301small-screen devices where long words may be displayed on a single line 7301small-screen devices where long words may be displayed on a single line
7302and require users to scroll horizontally. For the purposes of this 7302and require users to scroll horizontally. For the purposes of this
7303requirement, authors should ensure that content meets this requirement 7303requirement, authors should ensure that content meets this requirement
7304on standard desktop/laptop displays with the browser window maximized. 7304on standard desktop/laptop displays with the browser window maximized.
7305Since people generally keep their computers for several years, it is 7305Since people generally keep their computers for several years, it is
7306best not to rely on the latest desktop/laptop display resolutions but to 7306best not to rely on the latest desktop/laptop display resolutions but to
7307consider the common desktop/laptop display resolutions over the course 7307consider the common desktop/laptop display resolutions over the course
7308of several years when making this evaluation. 7308of several years when making this evaluation.
7309  7309 
7310Wrapping should always be possible as long as words are not so long that 7310Wrapping should always be possible as long as words are not so long that
7311a single word is more than half the width of a full screen. Very long 7311a single word is more than half the width of a full screen. Very long
7312URIs may run off the side of an enlarged screen, but they would not be 7312URIs may run off the side of an enlarged screen, but they would not be
7313considered text for "reading" and, therefore, would not violate this 7313considered text for "reading" and, therefore, would not violate this
7314provision. 7314provision.
7315  7315 
7316This provision does not mean that a user would never need to use 7316This provision does not mean that a user would never need to use
7317horizontal scrolling. It only means that they would not need to use 7317horizontal scrolling. It only means that they would not need to use
7318horizontal scrolling back and forth to read a line of text. For example, 7318horizontal scrolling back and forth to read a line of text. For example,
7319if a page consisted of two equal sized columns of text, it would 7319if a page consisted of two equal sized columns of text, it would
7320automatically meet this provision. Enlarging the page would mean that 7320automatically meet this provision. Enlarging the page would mean that
7321the first column was completely on screen and the user could just scroll 7321the first column was completely on screen and the user could just scroll
7322vertically down the page to read it. To read the second column, they 7322vertically down the page to read it. To read the second column, they
7323would horizontally scroll to the right, where the right hand column 7323would horizontally scroll to the right, where the right hand column
7324would then fit entirely within the width of the screen, and read that 7324would then fit entirely within the width of the screen, and read that
7325column without further horizontal scrolling. 7325column without further horizontal scrolling.
7326  7326 
7327  7327 
7328        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 1.4.8 7328        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 1.4.8
7329  7329 
7330This Success Criterion helps low vision users by letting them see text 7330This Success Criterion helps low vision users by letting them see text
7331without distracting presentational features. It lets them configure text 7331without distracting presentational features. It lets them configure text
7332in ways that will be easier for them to see by letting them control the 7332in ways that will be easier for them to see by letting them control the
7333color and size of blocks of text. 7333color and size of blocks of text.
7334  7334 
7335This Success Criterion helps people with cognitive, language and 7335This Success Criterion helps people with cognitive, language and
7336learning disabilities perceive text and track their location within 7336learning disabilities perceive text and track their location within
7337blocks of text. 7337blocks of text.
7338  7338 
7339  * 7339  *
7340  7340 
7341    People with some cognitive disabilities can read text better when 7341    People with some cognitive disabilities can read text better when
7342    they select their own foreground and background color combinations. 7342    they select their own foreground and background color combinations.
7343  7343 
7344  * 7344  *
7345  7345 
7346    People with some cognitive disabilities can track their locations 7346    People with some cognitive disabilities can track their locations
7347    more easily when blocks of text are narrow and when they can 7347    more easily when blocks of text are narrow and when they can
7348    configure the amount of space between lines and paragraphs. 7348    configure the amount of space between lines and paragraphs.
7349  7349

7351  7351

7353    when the spacing between words is regular. 7353    when the spacing between words is regular.

7359and double-spaced text in a paragraph. 7359and double-spaced text in a paragraph.

7362text)Example of space-and-a-half text. (a space equal to half the height 7362text)Example of space-and-a-half text. (a space equal to half the height
7363of a line of text line)Example of double-spaced text. (a space equal to 7363of a line of text line)Example of double-spaced text. (a space equal to
7364the height of a line of text between each line) 7364the height of a line of text between each line)

7840  7840 
7841    /Note: /Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are 7841    /Note: /Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are
7842    considered essential. 7842    considered essential.
7843  7843 
7844  7844 
7845      Intent of this Success Criterion 7845      Intent of this Success Criterion
7846  7846 
7847The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable people who require a 7847The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable people who require a
7848particular visual presentation of text to be able to adjust the text 7848particular visual presentation of text to be able to adjust the text
7849presentation as required. This includes people who require the text in a 7849presentation as required. This includes people who require the text in a
7850particular font size, foreground and background color, font family, line 7850particular font size, foreground and background color, font family, line
7851spacing or alignment. 7851spacing or alignment.
7852  7852 
7853This means implementing the text in a manner that allows its 7853This means implementing the text in a manner that allows its
7854presentation to be changed or providing a mechanism by which users can 7854presentation to be changed or providing a mechanism by which users can
7855select an alternate presentation. Using images of text is an example of 7855select an alternate presentation. Using images of text is an example of
7856an implementation that does not allow users to alter the presentation of 7856an implementation that does not allow users to alter the presentation of
7857the text within it. 7857the text within it.
7858  7858 
7859In some situations, a particular visual presentation of the text is 7859In some situations, a particular visual presentation of the text is
7860essential to the information being conveyed. This means that information 7860essential to the information being conveyed. This means that information
7861would be lost without that particular visual presentation. In this case 7861would be lost without that particular visual presentation. In this case
7862implementing the text in a manner that allows its presentation to be 7862implementing the text in a manner that allows its presentation to be
7863changed is not required. This includes text that demonstrates a 7863changed is not required. This includes text that demonstrates a
7864particular visual aspect of the text, such as a particular font family, 7864particular visual aspect of the text, such as a particular font family,
7865or text that conveys an identity, such as text within a company logo. 7865or text that conveys an identity, such as text within a company logo.
7866  7866 
7867Text that is decorative does not require implementing the text in a 7867Text that is decorative does not require implementing the text in a
7868manner that allows its presentation to be changed. 7868manner that allows its presentation to be changed.
7869  7869 
7870The definition of image of text contains the note: "Note: This does not 7870The definition of image of text contains the note: "Note: This does not
7871include text that is part of a picture that contains significant other 7871include text that is part of a picture that contains significant other
7872visual content." Examples of such pictures include graphs, screenshots, 7872visual content." Examples of such pictures include graphs, screenshots,
7873and diagrams which visually convey important information through more 7873and diagrams which visually convey important information through more
7874than just text. 7874than just text.
7875  7875

7898    *A quote* 7898    *A quote*
7899  7899 
7900    A Web page contains a quote. The quote itself is presented as 7900    A Web page contains a quote. The quote itself is presented as
7901    italicized text, indented from the left margin. The name of the 7901    italicized text, indented from the left margin. The name of the
7902    person to whom the quote is attributed is below the quote with 1.5x 7902    person to whom the quote is attributed is below the quote with 1.5x
7903    the line space and further indented from the left margin. CSS is 7903    the line space and further indented from the left margin. CSS is
7904    used to position the text; set the spacing between lines; as well as 7904    used to position the text; set the spacing between lines; as well as
7905    display the text's font family, size, color and decoration. 7905    display the text's font family, size, color and decoration.
7906  7906

7912    icon and text to describe their target. CSS is used to display the 7912    icon and text to describe their target. CSS is used to display the
7913    text's font family, size and foreground and background colors; as 7913    text's font family, size and foreground and background colors; as
7914    well as the spacing between the navigation links. 7914    well as the spacing between the navigation links.

7920    A Web site contains the organization's logo in the top left corner 7920    A Web site contains the organization's logo in the top left corner
7921    of each Web page. The logo contains logotype (text as part, or all, 7921    of each Web page. The logo contains logotype (text as part, or all,
7922    of the logo). The visual presentation of the text is essential to 7922    of the logo). The visual presentation of the text is essential to
7923    the identity of the logo and is included as a gif image which does 7923    the identity of the logo and is included as a gif image which does
7924    not allow the text characteristics to be changed. The image has a 7924    not allow the text characteristics to be changed. The image has a
7925    text alternative. 7925    text alternative.

7931    A Web page contains information about a particular font family. 7931    A Web page contains information about a particular font family.
7932    Substituting the font family with another font would defeat the 7932    Substituting the font family with another font would defeat the
7933    purpose of the representation. The representation is included as a 7933    purpose of the representation. The representation is included as a
7934    jpeg image which does not allow the text characteristics to be 7934    jpeg image which does not allow the text characteristics to be
7935    changed. The image has a text alternative. 7935    changed. The image has a text alternative.

7942    depiction of the letter in its original format is essential to 7942    depiction of the letter in its original format is essential to
7943    information being conveyed about the time period in which it was 7943    information being conveyed about the time period in which it was
7944    written. The letter is included as a gif image which does not allow 7944    written. The letter is included as a gif image which does not allow
7945    the text characteristics to be changed. The image has a text 7945    the text characteristics to be changed. The image has a text
7946    alternative. 7946    alternative.

7950    *Symbolic text characters* 7950    *Symbolic text characters*
7951  7951 
7952    A form allows users to enter blocks of text. The form provides a 7952    A form allows users to enter blocks of text. The form provides a
7953    number of buttons, including functions to style the text and check 7953    number of buttons, including functions to style the text and check
7954    spelling. Some of the buttons use text characters that do not form a 7954    spelling. Some of the buttons use text characters that do not form a
7955    sequence that expresses something in human language. For example "B" 7955    sequence that expresses something in human language. For example "B"
7956    to increase font weight, "I" to italicize the text and "ABC" to 7956    to increase font weight, "I" to italicize the text and "ABC" to
7957    check the spelling. The symbolic text characters are included as gif 7957    check the spelling. The symbolic text characters are included as gif
7958    images which do not allow the text characteristics to be changed. 7958    images which do not allow the text characteristics to be changed.
7959    The buttons have text alternatives. 7959    The buttons have text alternatives.
